	<item>
		<title>Lifelines of National Economy</title>
		<link>http://nxtclass.cu.cc/x/geo/lifelines-of-national-economy/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 30 Jan 2012 11:46:30 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>arkokoley</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://nxtclass.cu.cc/?page_id=55</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[[notes text="

<strong>Roadways:-</strong>

<strong></strong>India has about 2.3 million km. of road network.

<strong>Why roadways are preferred over railways?</strong>
<ul>
	<li>Easy to build even in rough terrain.</li>
	<li>Economically cheaper than railways.</li>
	<li>Provides door-to-door service, thereby reducing the loading-unloading cost.</li>
	<li>Construction cost is lower than railways.</li>
	<li>Used as feeder to railways and airways.</li>
	<li>Easily maintainable.</li>
</ul>
<strong>Road Density</strong><strong>:-</strong>
<ul>
	<li>Length of road per 100 sq. km. area is called road density.</li>
	<li>Road Density in India: <strong>75 km.</strong></li>
	<li>Minimum density: Jammu and Kashmir (10 km) Maximum density: Kerala (375 km)</li>
</ul>
&nbsp;

<strong>Classification of Roads</strong><strong>:-</strong>

<strong>Super Highways</strong><strong>:-</strong>
<ul>
	<li>Connect the mega cities of India.</li>
	<li>Project implemented by NHAI (National Highways Authority of India).</li>
	<li>Three components:</li>
</ul>
<blockquote>
<ol>
	<li><strong>Golden Quadrilateral: </strong>Linking Delhi, Mumbai, Chennai and Kolkata.</li>
	<li><strong>North–South corridor: </strong>Linking Srinagar (J &amp; K) with Kanyakumari (Tamil Nadu).</li>
	<li><strong>East-West Corridor: </strong>Linking Silcher (Assam) with Porbandar (Gujarat).</li>
</ol>
</blockquote>
<strong>National Highways:-</strong>
<ul>
	<li>Connect all major cities of the country.</li>
	<li>Constructed and maintained by the Central Public Works Department (CPWD).</li>
</ul>
<strong>State Highways:-</strong>
<ul>
	<li>Link the state capital with various district headquarters.</li>
	<li>Constructed and maintained by the State Public Works Department (SPWD).</li>
</ul>
<strong>District Roads:-</strong>
<ul>
	<li>Connect the district headquarters with other places of the district.</li>
	<li>Maintained by the Zila Parishad.</li>
</ul>
<strong>Border Roads:-</strong>
<ul>
	<li>Roads in the border areas of the country.</li>
	<li>Constructed and maintained by the Border Roads Organization (BRO) established in 1960.</li>
</ul>
&nbsp;

<strong>Railways</strong>
<ul>
	<li> Indian railways cover a route length of about 163000 km.</li>
	<li> It is used for transportation of freight and passengers.</li>
	<li> It is the largest public sector undertaking in India.</li>
	<li> First train ran from Mumbai to Thane (34 km) in 1853.</li>
	<li> 16 railways zones in the country.</li>
</ul>
<strong>Obstacles in laying railways tracks</strong>
<ul>
	<li>Rivers</li>
	<li>High mountains</li>
	<li>Uneven plateaus</li>
	<li>Sandy plains</li>
	<li>Swamps</li>
	<li>Forests</li>
</ul>
<strong>Railway Tracks</strong>
<ul>
	<li><strong>Broad gauge: </strong>1.676 m (Maximum route)</li>
	<li><strong>Metre gauge: </strong>1.000 m</li>
	<li><strong>Narrow gauge: </strong>0.762 m and 0.610 m</li>
</ul>
<strong>Pipelines</strong>

<strong>Uses</strong>
<ul>
	<li>Transport water.</li>
	<li>Transport crude oil.</li>
	<li>Transport Petroleum and natural gas from oil and gas fields to refineries.</li>
	<li>Transport gas to households.</li>
</ul>
<strong>Networks</strong>
<ul>
	<li>Assam oil field to Kanpur in U.P.</li>
	<li>Salaya in Gujarat to Jalandhar in Punjab. Its branches connect Koyali Chakshu.</li>
	<li>Gas pipeline from Hazira (Gujarat) to Jagdishpur (U.P.) via Vijaipur (M.P.)</li>
</ul>
&nbsp;

<strong>Waterways</strong>
<ul>
	<li>Cheapest means of transportation.</li>
	<li>Most suitable for transporting bulky cargo.</li>
	<li>Fuel efficient and environment friendly.</li>
	<li>Total length of inland navigation in India: 14500 km.</li>
	<li>Total length navigable by motorised boats: 3700 km.</li>
</ul>
<strong>National Waterways of India</strong>
<ul>
	<li><strong>N. W. No. 1: </strong>Ganga River (Allahabad to Haldia, 1620 km.)</li>
	<li><strong>N.W. No. 2: </strong>Brahmaputra River (Sadia to Dhubri, 891 km.)</li>
</ul>
<strong>N. W. No. 3: </strong>West Coast Canal (Kottampurma–Komman– Udyogamandal and Champakkara, 205 km.)
<ul>
	<li>Other inland waterways</li>
	<li>East–West Canal</li>
	<li>Damodar Valley Corporation Canal</li>
	<li>Buckingham Canal</li>
	<li>Sunderbans</li>
	<li>95% of India’s trade volume is transported by sea.</li>
	<li>Indian coastline: 7516 km.</li>
	<li>12 major and 181 medium and minor ports.</li>
</ul>
<strong>Kandla (Gujarat)</strong>
<ul>
	<li>First port developed after independence.</li>
	<li>It is a tidal port.</li>
</ul>
<strong>Mumbai (Maharashtra)</strong>
<ul>
	<li>Biggest port of India</li>
	<li>Natural port</li>
</ul>
<strong>Marmagoa (Goa)</strong>
<ul>
	<li>Iron exporting port.</li>
	<li>Accounts for 50% of India’s iron ore export.</li>
</ul>
<strong>New Mangalore Port (Karnataka)</strong>
<ul>
	<li>Exports iron ore from Kudremukh mines.</li>
</ul>
<strong>Cochin (Kerala)</strong>
<ul>
	<li>Located at the entrance of a lagoon.</li>
</ul>
<strong>Tuticorin (Tamil Nadu)</strong>
<ul>
	<li>Southernmost port of India.</li>
	<li>Handles trade with Sri Lanka and Maldives.</li>
</ul>
<strong>Chennai (Tamil Nadu)</strong>
<ul>
	<li>Oldest artificial port.</li>
</ul>
<strong>Vishakapatnam (Andhra Pradesh)</strong>
<ul>
	<li>Deepest land-locked port.</li>
</ul>
<strong>Paradwip (Orissa)</strong>
<ul>
	<li>Iron ore exports.</li>
</ul>
<strong>Kolkata (West Bengal)</strong>
<ul>
	<li>Inland riverine port.</li>
	<li>Tidal port.</li>
</ul>
<strong>Haldia (West Bengal)</strong>
<ul>
	<li>Subsidiary to Kolkata port.</li>
</ul>
&nbsp;

<strong>Airways</strong>
<ul>
	<li>Fastest and most comfortable means of transport.</li>
	<li>Most expensive.</li>
	<li>Air transport was nationalised in 1953.</li>
	<li>Indian Airlines and Air India are government carriers.</li>
	<li>Pawanhans helicopters provide services to ONGC.</li>
</ul>
<strong>Communication</strong>

<strong>Indian Postal Network</strong>
<ul>
	<li>Largest in the world.</li>
	<li>Six mail channels to facilitate quick delivery.</li>
</ul>
(1) Rajdhani Channel

(2) Metro Channel

(3) Green Channel

(4) Business Channel

(5) Bulk Channel

(6) Periodical Channel

<strong>Telecommunications</strong>
<ul>
	<li>Covers entire India.</li>
	<li>24 hour STD facility even in remote villages.</li>
</ul>
<strong>Mass Communication</strong>
<ul>
	<li>Radio: Akashwani (All India Radio)</li>
	<li>Television: Doordarshan</li>
	<li>Magazines</li>
	<li>Books</li>
	<li>Films: India is the largest producer of films</li>
	<li>Newspapers: In about 100 languages</li>
</ul>
&nbsp;

<strong>International Trade</strong>
<ul>
	<li>Trade between two countries.</li>
	<li>Carried through sea, air or land routes.</li>
	<li>An index of economic prosperity of a country.</li>
</ul>
&nbsp;

<strong>Balance of Trade: </strong>Difference between the exports and imports of a country.

&nbsp;

<strong>Items of Export from India</strong>
<ul>
	<li>Agriculture and allied products</li>
	<li>Ores and minerals</li>
	<li>Gems and jewellery</li>
	<li>Engineering goods</li>
</ul>
<strong>Commodities Imported in India</strong>
<ul>
	<li>Petroleum products</li>
	<li>Pearls and precious stones</li>
	<li>Inorganic chemicals</li>
	<li>Coal and coke</li>
	<li>Machinery</li>
	<li>Fertilisers</li>
</ul>
India is a software giant and earns through the export of information technology services to other nations.

<strong>Tourism</strong>
<ul>
	<li>India has a large tourism industry.</li>
	<li>About 2.5 million foreign tourists visit India every year.</li>
	<li>It provides employment to about 15 million people.</li>
	<li>Promotes national culture and local handicrafts.</li>
</ul>
"] ]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	<item>
		<title></title>
		<link>http://nxtclass.cu.cc/176/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 23 Feb 2012 06:08:48 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>admin</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://nxtclass.cu.cc/176/</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[ ]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>176</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2012-02-23 11:38:48</wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt>2012-02-23 06:08:48</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>176</wp:post_name>
		<wp:status>publish</wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>0</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>3</wp:menu_order>
		<wp:post_type>nav_menu_item</wp:post_type>
		<wp:post_password></wp:post_password>
		<wp:is_sticky>0</wp:is_sticky>
		<category domain="nav_menu" nicename="primary-navigation"><![CDATA[Primary Navigation]]></category>
		<wp:postmeta>

	<item>
		<title>Economics</title>
		<link>http://nxtclass.cu.cc/x/economics/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 23 Feb 2012 19:23:59 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>rupesh</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://nxtclass.cu.cc/?page_id=214</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<table>
<tbody>
<tr>
<td>1.</td>
<td>Development</td>
<td><span class="label label-info">CBSE</span></td>

	<item>
		<title>Light - Reflection and Refraction</title>
		<link>http://nxtclass.cu.cc/x/phy/light/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 24 Feb 2012 05:25:03 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>rupesh</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://nxtclass.cu.cc/?page_id=250</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<strong>Introduction</strong>

Light as a form of energy enables one to see objects clearly. Rectilinear propagation, reflection, refraction are certain properties associated with it. Reflection can be from plane and/or spherical surfaces. Refraction from plane surface and spherical lenses are also possible. In this chapter we will learn about the phenomena in the nature and the properties of light. Nature of image formation and various optical phenomena in nature are also discussed.]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>250</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2012-02-24 10:55:03</wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt>2012-02-24 05:25:03</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>light</wp:post_name>
		<wp:status>publish</wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>197</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>
		<wp:post_type>page</wp:post_type>
		<wp:post_password></wp:post_password>
		<wp:is_sticky>0</wp:is_sticky>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_edit_last</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[4]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_wp_page_template</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[default]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
	</item>
	<item>
		<title>Heredity and Evolution</title>
		<link>http://nxtclass.cu.cc/x/bio/heredity-and-evolution/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 24 Feb 2012 06:37:57 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>rupesh</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://nxtclass.cu.cc/?page_id=254</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[[summary text="

Reproductive processes give rise to new individuals that are similar but with some variations. Thus, the similarities between the parents and the offsprings are due to 'heredity' and the dissimilarities are due to 'variation'. Continuity of life is maintained through heredity and evolution. Heridity explains that organism resemble each other because they arise from common ansistor. Evolution is the orderly changes of various forms through a slow but a continuous process. It gives rise to more complex body designs even while simpler body designs continue to flourish.

<strong>Heredity</strong>
Transmission of characters (resemblances as well as variations) from parents to the offsprings, i.e., from one generation to the next is called heredity.

<strong>Variation</strong>
The differences shown by the individual of a species, and also by the offsprings (siblings) of the same parent are refferd to as variations.

<strong>Importance of Variations</strong>
<ul>
	<li>They enable organism to adapt themself in the changing environment.</li>
	<li>Variations form the basis of heredity.</li>
	<li>They form raw materials for the evolution and developement of new species.</li>
</ul>
<strong>Accumulation od Variation</strong>
<ul>
	<li>If one bacterium divides, then resultant two bacteria divide again, the four individual bacteria generated would be simi lar with minor differences due to small inaccuracies in DNA copying.</li>
	<li>Depending on the nature of variations, different individuals would have different advantages like bacteria, which can withstand heat will survive heat wave better.</li>
	<li>Selection of variants by environmental factors form the basis of evolutionary processes.</li>
</ul>
<strong>Heredity and Variation in Asexual Reproduction</strong>
<ul>
	<li>In asexual reproduction, organisms raised are the exact copies of their parents.</li>
	<li>They tend to preserve the similarities among all individuals belonging to a given line of descent.</li>
	<li>They exhibit very little variations due to some environmental factors or mutations which are sudden changes in genes. Outof these Two factors, only mutations are heritable.</li>
</ul>
<strong>Heredity and Variation in Sexual Reproduction</strong>
<ul>
	<li>In sexual reproduction, two parents are involved and there is formation and fusion of gametes.</li>
	<li>The offsprings show variations from their parents due to crossing over and exchange of gene segments.</li>
	<li>They are not carbon copies of their parents, due to recombination of parental genes. So, variations which occur areheritable.</li>
</ul>
<strong>Inherited Traits</strong>
It is the transmission of particular characteristics from parents to their offsprings, generation togeneration, which bear all basic features with great deal of variation. Inherited trait is a particular genetically determined characteristic that distinguishes a person.

<strong>Gregor Johann Mendel</strong>
<ul>
	<li>His experiments with garden peas (Pisum sativum) and the inferences together with his interpretationsconstitute the foundation of modern genetics.</li>
	<li>Mendel conducted his hybridization experiments in the garden behind the monastery.</li>
	<li>Mendel blended his knowledge of science and mathematics and was the first one to keep count of individuals exhibiting a particular trait in each generation.</li>
	<li>Mendel's experiments give us the mechanism for the inheritance of traits from one generation to the next.</li>
</ul>
<strong>Mendel's Experiment on Inheritance of Traits</strong>
Mendel used a number of contrasting visible characters of garden peas like round/wrinkled seeds, tall/short plants, white/voilet flowers, etc.

<strong>One visible contrasting character</strong>
<ul>
	<li>Mendel took pea plants with different characteristics as a tall plant and a short plant.</li>
	<li>The first generation or F1 progeny thus formed are all tall.</li>
	<li>Mendel then allowed the F1 progeny plants for self-pollination.</li>
	<li>The second generation or F2 progeny of the F1 tall plants are not all tall, some are short. This indicates thatboth tallness and shortness traits were inherited in F1 plants but only the tallness trait was expressed.</li>
	<li>Thus, two copies of the traits are inherited in each sexually reproducing organism.</li>
	<li>In the figure, both TT and Tt are tall plants, while onlytt is a short plant.</li>
	<li>A single copy of T is enough to make plant tall while both copies have to be ‘t ‘for the plant to beshort. Therefore, traits like 'T' are dominant traits while 't" recessive traits.</li>
</ul>
<strong>Two visible contrasting character</strong>
<ul>
	<li>Mendel took pea plants with two different characteristics such as a tall plant with round seeds and a short plant withwrinkled-seeds.</li>
	<li>F1 progeny are all tall with round seeds, thus, tallness and round seeds are dominant traits.</li>
	<li>F2 progeny are tall plants with round seeds and some short plants with wrinkled seeds.</li>
	<li>But some F2 progeny shows new mixtures like tall having wrinkled seeds and short having round seeds.</li>
	<li>Therefore, tall / short trait and round seed/ wrinkled seed trait sare independently inherited.</li>
</ul>
<strong>Control of Traits</strong>
<ul>
	<li>A section of DNA that provides information for one protein in cell is called gene for that protein.</li>
	<li>If the proteins work efficiently, the traits get expressed in abetter-way.</li>
	<li>For example, plant height depends on the amount of growth hormone released by protein. If the protein is efficient, moregrowth hormone will be released and the plant will be taller.But if the protein is inefficient, the plant will be shorter. Thusgenes control the traits.</li>
</ul>
<strong>Mechanism of Inheritance</strong>
<ul>
	<li>If both parents help to determine the trail in the progeny, both parents must be contributing a copy of the same gene.</li>
	<li>Thus, each pea plant must have two sets of all genes, one inherited from each parent, so each germ cell must have only one gene set.</li>
	<li>Each gene set is present , not as a single long thread of DNA, but as separate independent pieces each called chromosome and each cell will have two copies of each chromosome one each frommale and female parents.</li>
	<li>When two germ cells combine, they will restore the normal number of chromosomes in the progeny, ensuring the stability of DNAspecies.</li>
	<li>Therefore, such mechanism of inheritance explains the-results of Mendel's experiments and isused by all sexually and asexually reproducing organisms.</li>
</ul>
<strong>Chromosomes</strong> are long thread like structures present in the nucleus of a cell which contain hereditary information of the cell.

<strong>Gene </strong>is the unit of inheritance. It is therefore, a unit of specific biological function. Gene is the part of a chromosome which controls the appearance of a set of hereditary characteristics.

<strong>Deoxyribonucleic Acid (DNA)</strong> is a chemical in the chromosome which carries the hereditary characters or traits in a coded form from one generation to the next in all the organism.

<strong>Sex Determination</strong>

Different species use different strategies for sex determination.
<ul>
	<li>In some animals, environmental factors, the temperature at which fertilised eggs are kept determines whether the animals developing in the eggs will be male or female.</li>
	<li>In other animals such as snails, individuals can change sex, indicating that sex is not genetically determined. In human beings, the sex of the individual is genetically, determined.</li>
	<li>Sex determination is the process by which sex of a new born individual can be determined.</li>
	<li>Human beings have 22 paired chromosomes and one pair called sex chromosome which is not a perfect pair.</li>
	<li>A male has one X chromosome and one Y chromosome, i.e., half of the male gametes or sperms will have X chromosome and the other half will have Y chromosome.</li>
	<li>A female has two X chromosomes, i.e., all the female gametes or ova will have only X chromosomes.</li>
<ol type="(i)">
	<li>If a sperm carrying X chromosome fertilises an ovum which carries X chromosome, then the child born will be a girl.</li>
	<li>If a sperm carrying Y chromosome fertilises an ovum which carries X chromosome, then the child born will be a boy.</li>
</ol>
	<li>Thus, the sperm determines the sex of the child.</li>
</ul>
<strong>Evolution
</strong>It is the sequence of gradual changes which take place in the primitive organisms over millions of years and new species are produced. Since the evolution is of the living organisms, so it is called 'Organic Evolution'.

<strong>Variation in Population (Example)
</strong>12 red beetles live in a green leafy bush by sexual reproduction and generate variation.
<blockquote><strong>Situation-I</strong></blockquote>
<ul>
	<li>Crows eat these beetles, leaving only fewer beetles available for reproduction.</li>
	<li>Due to colour variation during reproduction, only one green beetle evolves and therefore, all its progeny beetles become green.</li>
	<li>Crows cannot see green coloured beetles on green leaves and hence cannot eat them, resulting more green beetles than red ones in the beetle population.</li>
	<li>This type of variation gives a survival advantage.</li>
</ul>
<blockquote><strong>Situation-II</strong></blockquote>
<ul>
	<li>Due to colour variation during reproduction, a blue colour beetle appears and all its progeny beetles become blue.</li>
	<li>Crows can see both red and blue beetles and therefore, eat them.</li>
	<li>Initially there are less number of blue beetles and more of red beetles.</li>
	<li>Then an elephant stumps on the bushes and kills most of the beetles. By chance,few beetles that survived were mostly blue.</li>
	<li>Thus, the blue beetle population slowly expands.</li>
	<li>There is no survival advantage on this variation and provides diversity without adaptation.</li>
</ul>
<blockquote><strong>Situation-III</strong></blockquote>
<ul>
	<li>As the beetle population begins to expand, the bushes suffer from a disease and amount of leaf available for beetles have reduced.</li>
	<li>Thus, the beetles are poorly nourished and the average weight of an adult beetle has decreased.</li>
	<li>After few years, the plant disease is eliminated and enough food is available for the beetles. Thus, the beetles have come back to its normal size and weight.</li>
	<li>This change is not inherited over generation.</li>
</ul>
<div><strong>Acquired Trait</strong></div>
<div>It is a particular characteristics that is developed during the lifetime of an individual. Such characteristics are not genetically controlled and cannot be passed on to next generation.</div>
<div></div>
<div><strong>Charles Robot Darwin</strong></div>
<div>He was a British naturalists who formulated his hypothesis that evolution took place due to natural selection. Darwin's theory of evolution tells us how life evolved from simple to more complex forms.</div>
<div><strong>Origin of life on Earth</strong></div>
<div>J.B.S. Haldane, a British scientist suggested in 1929 that life must have developed from simple inorganic molecules which were present on the earth to more complex organic molecules. Thus, the first primitive organism would arise form further chemical synthesis.</div>
<div><strong>Speciation</strong></div>
<div>It is the evolution of the reproductive isolation among once-interbreeding populations, i.e., the development of one or more species from existing species.</div>
<div><strong>Micro-evolution</strong></div>
<div>It is the evolution on the relatively small scale, involving the emergence of new species or of new group below the species level, such as races and the subspecies which are significant. They also change the common characteristics of a particular species.</div>
<div><strong>Gene-Flow</strong></div>
<div>It is the exchange of genetic material by interbreeding between the populations of the same species or between the individuals within the population. Gene flow increase the variation in the genetic composition of a population.</div>
<div><strong>Genetic Drift</strong></div>
<div>It is the random change in the frequency of alleles in a population over successive generations due to sampling error in the gametes.</div>
<div>
<ul>
	<li>Each new generation differ from its parental generation with regard to allele frequencies simply because of random variation in the distribution of gametes.</li>
	<li>This process is more rapid in smaller population, hence genetic drift can cause loss of genetic diversity if there are no genetic counteracting factors.</li>
	<li>Over generations to come genetic drift will accumulate different changes in sub-population.</li>
</ul>
<strong>Natural Selection</strong>"]

[ncert text="

<strong>1. If a trait an exits in 10% of a population of an asexually reproducing species and trait B exist in 60% of the same population, which trait is likely to have arisen earlier?</strong>Ans. Trait B is likely to have arisen earlier as in asexual reproduction traits are passed on directly from one generation to other with hardly any variation.

<strong>2. How does the creation of variation in a species promote survival?</strong>

Ans. Sometimes for a species, the environmental conditions changes drastically making their survival difficult. For example, if the temperature of habitat increases suddenly, most of the bacteria living in it would die. However, a few heat resistant’s would survive and, thus help in the survive of the species.

However, variations are not so beneficial for individual organisms.

<strong>3. How do Mendel’s experiment’s show that traits may be dominant or recessive?</strong>

Ans. Mendel selected true breeding tall and dwarf (tt) pea plants. The seeds formed after cross pollination between these plants that represented the f<sub>1</sub> generation on self-pollination the f<sub>1 </sub>plants the f<sub>2</sub> generation was obtain in which one – fourth of the plant were short

From this it can be concluded that the f<sub>1</sub> tall plants carry traits of being both tall and short, but appear tall as the tall trait is dominant over the short trait.

<strong>4. How do Mendel’s experiments show that traits are inherited independently?</strong>

Ans. Mendel crossed pea plants having round green seeds (RRyy) with those having wrinkled yellow seeds (rrYY). The seed so formed of the f<sub>1 </sub>generation were yellow wrinkled. Although they had both the characters in them, the yellow round traits are dominant, so the f1 plants have round yellow seeds.

On self-pollinating the f1 progeny, the f2 progeny was found to have yellow round seeds, green round seeds, yellow wrinkled seeds and green wrinkled seed in the ratio 9:3:3:1.

This reveals that the traits are inherited independently and not in groups.

<strong>5. A man with blood group A marries women with blood group O and their daughter has blood group O. Is this information enough to tell which of the traits-blood group A or O is dominant? Why or Why not?</strong>

Ans. No, this information is not sufficient to determine which trait is dominant. This is because we do not know about the blood group of all the progeny.

<strong>6. How is the sex of the child determined in human being?</strong>

Ans. In humans, females have a XX sex chromosome, whereas the males have a XY Sex chromosome while fertilization, the female gamete provides on X chromosome while the male gamete provides either X or Y that determines whether the baby will be a male or female.

<strong>7. What are the different ways in which individuals with a particular trait may increase in the population?</strong>

Ans. Individuals with a particular trait may increase in the population due to:
<ol>
	<li>Natural selection, when the trait offers some survival advantage.</li>
	<li>Genetic drift; when some genes governing that trait become common in the population.</li>
	<li>Acquired traits; when that trait gets acquired during the individual lifetime.</li>
</ol>
<strong>8. Why are traits acquired during the life time of an individual not inherited?</strong>

Ans. This is because an acquired trait does not involve change in the genes or the reproductive tissues which cannot be passed on to the germ cells of the progeny. Therefore, these traits are not inherited.

<strong>9. Why are small numbers of surviving tigers a cause of worry from the point of view of genetics?</strong>

Ans. Small numbers of tigers mean that fewer genetic variations are available. This means that on reproducing, tigers have a lesser chance of producing progeny with variations that may prove useful. This is a cause of worry from the point of view of genetics.

<strong>10. What factors could lead to the rise of new species?</strong>

Ans. Natural selection, genetic drift and acquisition of traits during the lifetime of an individual can give rise to new species.

<strong>11. Will geographic isolation be a major factor in the speciation of a self-pollination species?</strong>

Ans. No, as the plant are self-pollination, i.e., the pollen is transferred from the anther to the stigma of the some flower or flower of the some plant, geographical isolation cannot prevent speciation in this case.

<strong>12. Give an example of characteristics being used to determine how close two species are in evolutionary terms?</strong>

Ans. The presence of feathers in dinosaurs and birds indicates that they are evolutionarily related. For dinosaurs, feathers provided insulation. However, they came to be used for flight by birds. This proves the reptiles and birds are closely related and that the evolution of wings started in reptiles.

<strong>13. Can the wings of butterfly and the wings of a bat be considered homologous organs? Why or why not?</strong>

Ans. The wings of butterfly are similar to these of a bat in terms of function as both serve the purpose of flying. However, they are not similar in structure. Therefore, they are analogous organs, not homologous.

<strong>14. What are fossils? What do they tells us about the process of evolution?</strong>

Ans. Fossils are the imprinted remains of prehistoric organisms. They represent the ancestors of the organisms we see today. They provide evolutionary evidence by revealing changes that have occurred during the passage of time to give rise to the prevent breed of organisms.

<strong>15. Why are human beings who look so different from each other in terms of size, colour and looks said to belong to the same species?</strong>

Ans. Skin colour, looks, size, etc are all variety of features present due in environmental variation. There is no biological bias to the concept of races. Therefore, all humans are of a single species as humans of different colour, size and looks are capable of reproducing to produce a healthy offspring.

<strong>16. In evolutionary terms, can we say which among bacteria, spiders, fish and chimpanzees have a better body design? Why or why not?</strong>

Ans. No. we cannot say that a particular organism has a better body design as complexity in body design due to evolution cannot always be equated with progress or betterment. Sometimes, simple body designs are better than complex ones. For example, bacteria can survive in a variety of extreme condition due to their simple body design.

<strong>17. A study found that children with light coloured eyes are likely to have parents with light coloured eyes. On this basis can we say anything about whether the light eye colour is dominant or the light eye colour is dominant or recessive? Why or why not?</strong>

Ans. No, it cannot be said whether light eye colour I dominant or recessive. Let us assume that the children have either LL or Ll or ll genotype. If they have LL genotype, the their parents too will have LL genotype.

If the children have ll genotype, them the parents will have ll genotype.

<strong>18. How are the areas of study evolution and classification interlinked?</strong>

Ans. Classification involves grouping of organisms into a formal system based on similarities in body structure on evolutionary history. Two species, with more recent ancestor are likely to be grouped together.

"]

</div>]]></content:encoded>

	</item>
	<item>
		<title>Circles</title>
		<link>http://nxtclass.cu.cc/x/maths/circles/</link>
		<pubDate>Sat, 25 Feb 2012 08:55:04 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>admin</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://nxtclass.cu.cc/?page_id=269</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<div id="accordion" class="accordion">
<div class="accordion-group">
<div class="accordion-heading"><a class="accordion-toggle" href="#notes" data-toggle="collapse" data-parent="accordion">Notes</a></div>
<div id="notes" class="accordion-body collapse">

<ul>
<li>
A circle may be regarded as a collection of points in a plane at a fixed distance from a fixed point. The fixed point is called the centre of the circle. The fixed distance between the centre of the circle and the circumference, is called radius.
</li>
<li>
The perimeter of the circle is referred to as the circumference of the circle.
</li>
<li>
A chord of a circle is a line segment joining any two points on the circumference.
</li>
<li>
An arc of a circle is a part of the circumference.
</li>
<li>
A diameter of a circle is a chord which passes through the centre of the circle.
</li>
<li>
A line, which intersects the circle in two distinct points, is called a secant.
</li>
<li>
A line which has only one point common to the circle is called a tangent to the circle.
</li>
<li>
There is one and only one tangent at a point of the circle.
</li>
<li>
The tangent at any point of a circle is perpendicular to the radius through the point of contact.
</li>
<li>
No tangent can be drawn from a point inside the circle.
</li>
<li>
The lengths of tangents drawn from an external point to a circle are equal.
</li>
<li>
The perpendicular at the point of contact to the tangent to a circle passes through the centre of the circle.
</li>
<li>
Tangents drawn at the end points of a diameter of a circle are parallel.
</li>
</ul>

</div>
</div></div>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>269</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2012-02-25 14:25:04</wp:post_date>

		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>circles</wp:post_name>
		<wp:status>publish</wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>200</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>
		<wp:post_type>page</wp:post_type>

	</item>
	<item>
		<title>A Shady Plot</title>
		<link>http://nxtclass.cu.cc/x/eng/shady-plot/</link>
		<pubDate>Sat, 25 Feb 2012 12:29:51 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>rupesh</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://nxtclass.cu.cc/?page_id=284</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[[introduction text="

A 'Shady Plot' by Elsie Brown is a ghost story. Unlike the other ghost stories which are quite scary and gruesome, this story is humorous. Humour arises out of the narrator's ability to laugh at himself and his situation. It is quite amusing to note that a ghost shakes the confidence of the narrator in his writing abilities.

"]

[story text="

John, The narrator, wrote ghost stories because they were in the demand. For earning his living, he served as an accountant in a company. Once he was asked by his publisher Jenkins to write a ghost story. The narrator reluctantly agreed to do so. When he was all alone on his room, he started thinking of the plot of his story. He remained blank for some time. The moment he said, 'This writing business is delightful, isn't it ?', he was shocked to hear a voice, 'Yes... I should say it is !' Soon a ghost appeared in parts. The ghost named Helen told him how she had been assisting him with ideas about his stories in the past. She said that she and her co-ghost were now on strike. So she would not help him until he persuaded all his friends and acquaintances to stop using the Ouija board being used to call them (ghosts and spirits). The ghost disappeared when the narrator's wife appeared.

The narrator's wife, Lavinia, and her friends were interested in Ouija board games. Once they organised such a game to call on the spirits. Lavinia forced her husband to join. When the ladies started using the board, the board behaved strangely. It spelt 'traitor' and then 'Helen'. The ladies came to know that someone by the name Helen wanted to communicate with John. Lavinia was shocked. After The ladies had departed,  she informed her husband that she was going back to her grandmother and would take divorce. John felt shattered and helpless. Gladiola, the African maid, also wanted to leave as she was afraid of magic and hoodoo. In order to stop her from going, Lavania asked her to burn her Ouija board. After she had said so, the ghost of Helen again appeared. John did not want his wife to see the ghost lest she should swoon. However, Lavinia did see the ghost and talked to her. She remained calm and composed. She realized her folly. After the ghost had departed, the narrator felt a sudden strong desire to write. He had got an excellent plot for a story.

"]

[character text="

<strong>John Hallock:</strong>

John Hallock is quite imaginative and creative and writes popular ghost stories. He is loving and caring husband. He tries to fulfil all the desires of his wife. He dose not mind his wife's fads and spendthrift nature. He is not afraid of ghosts. That is why, he confronts the ghost of Helen and even indulges in banter with her. He is shy by nature and reluctantly touches the fingers of a young lady, his partner at the Ouija board game.

<strong>Lavinia Hallock:</strong>

Lavinia Hallock, the narrator's wife, loves novelty and thrills. She has formed her Book Club. She is fond of using Ouija board to communicate with the spirits. She is quite spendthrift. She spends a lot of money on grocery and fancy shopping. she is suspicious and jealous. She thinks that her husband was flirtatious and was having an affair. So she decides to divorce him. But she soon realizes her mistake. She is not as weak-willed as her husband thinks her to be.

"]

[theme text="

The story 'A Shady Plot' is a ghost story. Unlike other ghost stories which are frightening, this story is humorous. It brings home the idea that some ghosts, if the have real existence, are good and benevolent by nature. Human beings tend to communicate with the spirits and ghosts, which is abnormal and undesirable. We should let the spirits of the other world undisturbed. Calling on them through dubious means may prove to be harmful.

"]

[title text="

The title of the story is quite adaptive and suggestive. The word 'shady' refers to something dubious, whereas 'plot' refers to secret plan. The shady plot, thus, refers to dubious and questionable existence of ghost of Helen that appears in the story in a quite funny way. The ghost comes to disturb the placid life of the narrator and his wife, but luckily fails to do so.

"]

[saq text="

<strong>1. Why was the writer getting over confident about his ability of writing ghost stories?</strong>

Ans : Mr Hallock, the writer had always managed to write good ghost stories, though he was not a specialist in these kind of stories. Such stories were greatly in public demand. He was confident that somehow or the other, a good plot always appeared from somewhere and he was able to write a good story.

<strong>2. Watching the ghost taking shape was ‘Like watching of the moving picture cartoons put together,’ how?</strong>

Ans : Helen, the ghost, appeared in parts. First, a hand took shape, then some other body part, so on and so forth. The process in which the final apparition appeared in the end, was a matter of surprise. The ghost always took shape in bits and pieces like a cartoon in a moving picture.

<strong>3. What surprising revelation is made by the ghost? Why did the writer not believe her?</strong>

Ans : The writer was greatly surprised to discover that all the good plots of ghost stories had been supplied to him by the ghost Helen. The writer disbelieved her because he had never really seen her before. But the ghost said that she had sat on his shoulders and suggested the plots for his stories.

<strong>4. Why is the ghost fed up of the Ouija Board fanatics?</strong>

Ans : The ghosts are now fed up of being called again and again for answers and queries. They were pulled out of beds at odd times, so they were very tired. The Ouija Board crazy fans would keep asking questions, so this irritated the ghosts and proved to be tiresome and troublesome.

<strong>5. What reasons are given by Lavinia for not getting rid of the Ouija Board?</strong>

Ans : Lavinia felt that the Ouija board was procured at bargain price. Moreover she felt that it would help her husband in writing ghost stories. It would also provide an interesting activity for her book-club meetings.

<strong>6. Why was the narrator shocked to see the activities of his wife’s Book Club?</strong>

Ans : The narrator was in for a great shock to see that all the ladies of his wife’s book-club were sitting near a Ouija Board. Helen, the ghost, had threatened the narrator that he must exert all his force to dissuade people from using the Ouija Board and keep calling ghosts now and then for their problems. So to see so many ladies using the board was a painful sight for him.

<strong>7. What controversy or furore was caused in the parlour by the name of ‘Helen’?</strong>

Ans : The narrator was forced to be a partner in the Ouija board game and to his horror he discovered that he was called a ‘traitor’ by the ghost. When Miss Hinkle wished to know the details, it was revealed on the Ouija Board that the person, who had called the narrator, a traitor, was someone with the name ‘Helen’ This name created controversy since the narrator’s wife did not know anyone with that name.

<strong>8. Helen the ghost says, ‘‘ I’m too tired to materialise’’. What does she imply by the above statement?</strong>

Ans : Helen was too tired because she had to work overtime the earlier night answering all the questions of Lavinia’s friends. She took longer than before to appear in her full shape because she couldn't be expected to retain all her faculties after answering all the Ouija Board fanatics of Lavinia’s book-club, all the night.

<strong>9. Why did Helen pay a visit to the narrator again?</strong>

Ans : Helen paid a visit to the narrator because she had been sent to ensure that the narrator’s wife should get rid of the Ouija Board. She had come to threaten the writer and if he did not pay any heed then she would not help the narrator to suggest new plots for his stories.

<strong>10. Lavinia entered the narrator’s room with a solid finality. What was her purpose?</strong>

Ans : Lavinia had become suspicious of the narrator that he was involved with some woman called ‘Helen’. So she had come to tell her husband that she was leaving him and moving out. She could not tolerate the infidelity of her husband.

<strong>11. Why was the narrator unable to conceal Helen behind his back before his wife?</strong>

Ans : Lavinia refused to stand on one side, so she jumped quickly to see who was standing behind her husband. She was already suspicious and noticed that her husband was trying to conceal someone behind his back. Even Helen did not disappear so both the women confronted each other first time.

<strong>12. How did Lavinia react after facing Helen?</strong>

Ans : The writer had always thought that Lavinia was weak-hearted and she might faint at the sight of the ghost. But nothing like this happened. The interaction proved positive and Lavinia stood boldly and confidently before the ghost.

<strong>13. Why did the narrator have a strong urge to pen down his new story?</strong>

Ans : The narrator had undergone a great experience. It was scary, interesting, revealing and an excellent plot for any ghost story. A ghost story based on this kind of story was going to be a sure hit.

<strong>14. What did Jenkins do to earn his living ?</strong>

Ans: Jenkins was a writer, bur even then he had to serve as a accountant in an office to earn his living. He had not reached the point of being a whole time writer.

<strong>15. Who was Helen ? Why did she came before the narrator ?</strong>

Ans: Helen was a female ghost. She appeared before the narrator when he was about to write a ghost story. He was witout any idea about the plot of his story. When he was talking to himself, Helen appeared slowly in parts.

<strong>16. Why had the ghost appeared ?</strong>

Ans: The ghost Helen had appeared to tell the narrator that she and her co-ghosts helping writers like him were n strike. The ghosts were fed up with too many calls of assistance from human beings.

<strong>17. Who was Lavinia ? What made her decide to leave her husband ?</strong>

Ans: Lavinia was the narrator's wife. She thought that her husband had an affair with the lady called Helen. So she decided to leave her husband and even to divorce him.

<strong>18. Why did Lavinia change her mind to leave her husband?</strong>

Ans: Lavinia changed her mind to leave hr husband after having seen the ghost of Helen herself. She realized her mistake. She learnt that Helen was not a living human being but a ghost who once lived in New York.

<strong>19. When did the writer come to have the idea of an excellent plot of a ghost story ?</strong>

Ans: The writer can=me to have an idea of an excellent plot of a ghost story after his wife had decided to burn her Ouija board. The ghost of Helen was satisfied. She might have assisted the narrator with the idea of his new story now.

<strong>20. Who is Gladolia ? Why did she wish to leave the narrator's house ? What made her give up the idea ?</strong>

Ans: Gladolia was an African maid in the narrator's house. She wished to leave the narrator's house because she was afraid of magic and hoodo. She gave up the idea when the narrator's wife agreed to burn her magical Ouija board.

"]

[laq text="

<strong>1. John had become a nervous wreck. It had been a hard journey back to normalcy and marital bliss. He writes a diary entry expressing these feelings. Write this for him.</strong>

Ans: Dear Diary,

What a harrowing and emotional nightmare I have gone through! On God! These days will always remain permanently etched in my memory. Imagine a ghost helping you with the stories and thus causing your marriage to break. How I was saved at the last minute, is a marvel? Those days when Helen had threatened me and then Lavinia refused to give up the Ouija board; I was blamed for infidelity, I could neither sleep nor walk out. I wish I had confided in my wife before. Thank God! Everything is normal as before. But this traumatic period of time, I will never forget. All is well that ends well.

John Hallock.

<strong>2. John’s new ghost story is a hit and proves to be a best seller. Jenkins throws a party in his honour and John is asked to give a speech regarding the success of his work and the inspiration behind it. Prepare the speech of him.</strong>

Ans: Dear friends,

I am deeply obliged for your best wishes and support for my success. Believe me friends, I am not an expert in ghost stories but somehow a good plot occurs out of the blue and becomes the solid ground of my stories. I know, you find my stories very fascinating and thrilling as most ghost stories are. Well, stories can only work if there is someone to inspire or guide you. Even I have an angel sitting on my shoulders to steer the course of my stories. I hope it continues this way.

Thanks.

<strong>3. Helen, the ghost had close encounters with human beings like John. She goes back to her world and mulls over this experience she had on earth. She writes a diary entry regarding the behaviour of human beings and the fickleness of their relationships. Write this diary entry for her.</strong>

Ans: Dear Diary,

This was my first opportunity to have close encounters with human beings for a long stretch of time. Basically we stay out of bounds but now I was forced to materialise in person and threaten John, as there was no other option. I know John is basically a good guy, vulnerable and kind but his wife is too dominating. He is so scared of her and she started doubting her husband at the mention of a mere word ‘Helen’. John was trying to hide me, not to distress her but, look how she behaved. These human beings have fickle relationships, despite all. I think we are better off for we keep our relationships intact Helen.

<strong>4. Do you believe ‘A Shady Plot’ qualifies as a good ghost story?</strong>

Ans: Yes, this is a very good story with the most interesting storyline and plot. The plot has been inspired from a real life experience which makes it authentic. It has suspense, it is scary with ghosts walking in and out, but the best part is the humour. The story is not the stereotype one, it is funny and hilarious. It is very interesting to know that even ghosts get fed up of haunting and they are dragged out of their beds at all hours. This story is full of surprises and that is the best quality of a ghost story.

"]

[ncert text="

<center><strong>Short</strong></center><strong>1. What genre of stories does Jenkins want the narrator to write ? Why ?</strong>

Ans: Jenkins wants the narrator to write supernatural or ghost stories. The public wants to read real 'horror' stuff. It is the public demand which compels him to ask the narrator to write another ghost story.

<strong>2. Does the narrator like writing ghost stories ? Support your answer with evidence from the story.</strong>

Ans: The narrator doesn't like writing the ghost stories. Even then he has to write them because he cannot say 'no' to his first publisher Jekins and also because he needs money to satisfy the endless demands of his wife.

<strong>3. What makes Helen, the ghost, and her co-ghosts organise the Writer's Inspiration Bureau ?</strong>

Ans: Helen and her co-ghosts organise the Writer's Inspiration Bureau to help those writers who wish to write stroies find themselves without ideas and whose minds are quite soft to accept impression.

<strong>4. Why had Helen, the ghost, been helping the narrator write ghost stories ? Why was she gong on strike ? What conditions did she place for providing continued help ?</strong>

Ans: Helen, the ghost had been helping the narrator write ghost stories as she worked for the Writer's Inspiration Bureau and had been a writer when she was alive. She and he co-ghosts were going on strike because they were fed up of being called out of their beds too often from the people for assistance, particularly from the users of Ouija board. She said the narrator would have to help to persuade people not to use Ouija board if he needed her help any more.

<strong>5. How does the ghost undermine the narrator’s faith in his ability to write ghost stories?</strong>

Ans: The ghost undermines the narrator's faith in his ability to write the ghost stories by telling him how she has been helping him with all those ideas about his stories. Without her help he would not have written his stories.

<strong>6. Why does John want the ghost to disappear before his wife appears on the scene? What impression of his wife’s character do you form from his words?</strong>

Ans: John doesn't want his wife to see the ghost least she should become hysterical and faint. He thinks his wife weak-willed.

<strong>7. Why does the narrator hesitate to be a partner to Laura Hinkle during Ouija Board party?</strong>

Ans: The narrator hesitates to be the partner to Laura Hinkle because he is quite shy and doesn't want to be touched by Laura in any way. Perhaps he is also hesitant in the presence of his wife. Also, he fears the ghost- Helen- who, if sees him now using an Ouija Board, might do something to him.

<strong>8. What message does the ghost convey to the group that had assembled in the narrator’s house? What is their reaction to the message?</strong>

Ans: The ghost story conveys the message that it is not good and desirable to call the ghosts unnecessarily. The group at the Ouija board Party seems to have understood the message. That is why, the narrator's wife asks her maid to use the Ouija board for kindling wood.

<strong>9. Do you agree with narrator calling the assembly of women ‘manipulators’. Give reasons.</strong>

Ans: The narrator calls the assembly of women 'manipulators' as he does not believe that someone can call his name through their Ouija boards as Helen was interacting through his board. The women, he believes, are only trying to create trouble for him.

<strong>10. Why is John’s wife angry? What does she decide to do?</strong>

Ans: John's wife is angry as she comes to believe that he is having an affair with a women called Helen. She decides to go back to her grandmother and divorce her husband.

<strong>11. Why does John wish he were dead?</strong>

Ans: John wishes he were dead on learning that his wife is going back to her grandmother and intends to divorce him. He was unable to bear the very idea of it.

<strong>12. When confronted by Lavinia about his flirtations over the Ouija Board, John insists that 'The affair was quite over-board, I assure you', Bring out the pun in this statement.</strong>

Ans: A pun is a play on a words for two disparate meanings. In John's statement the pun is involved in the word 'over-board'. It means what happened between the John and Laura Hinkle- The touching of fingers- was over the Ouija board. It also means that there is nothing secretive about anything. He is open and honest in the matter.

<strong>13. John’s apprehensions about his wife’s reaction to her encounter with the ghost are unfounded. Justify.</strong>

Ans: When John's wife finally encountered the ghost she did not become hysterical and swoon, as was earlier apprehended by the him. She proved to be quite brave and strong.

<center><strong>Long</strong></center><strong>1. After her reconciliation with her husband, John Hallock, Lavinia writes a letter to her friend expressing how her relationship with him had almost been on the verge of breaking and what saved it. Write her letter.</strong>

Ans:
Post Street
10 September,
20 xx Dear Anne,

I am extremely sorry for not responding earlier. My life had taken a strong turn and I was left grappling with some apprehensions. Believe me, you were uppermost in my mind but I wanted to sort out my domestic problems and then write to you with a clear frame of mind.
Last month I underwent a very bad phase of my life. You know how proud I am of John and his creative abilities. I have always appreciated his skill in churning out excellent stories along with being a considerate husband. He has always supported me in my endeavors, but sometimes even honesty is also put to test. Once during the Book Club game with my friends, the Ouija board hinted that John was having an affair with someone called Helen. I was dumb founded and I threatened to quit. You know, I am impatient I can never tolerate infidelity. I had packed my suitcase and was on the verge of deserting John, when I discovered to my surprise, it was an apparition, a ghost, named Helen who was haunting him. Who would believe that ghosts are found in today’s world? Nevertheless I’m happy that I discovered the truth eventually. Now all is well and there is no reason to worry. However, I blame myself for all this ruckus. I never gave him chance to explain, nor did I show faith in him. I should have remained unflinching in my trust. So the famous quote proved true in my case ‘‘Jealousy, thy name is woman’’. I have learnt my lesson now.
Please write to me about yourself also.
Your friend
Lavinia.

<strong>2. Discuss the significance of the title of the lesson, ‘‘A Shady Plot’’.</strong>

Ans: The title ‘A Shady Plot’ is most appropriate because most of the situations and characters remain unclear and foggy. At first instance the writer is plagued by doubts regarding the plot of the story. He tries really hard and it appears he is chasing the shadows in search of a ghost story. The appearance of the ghost is open to interpretation. Is it there, is it not there. There is doubt regarding the existence of Helen, she is spooky and gives rise to apprehensions. The existence of Helen is questionable, no one else will believe it, it is beyond the realm of reality. Moreover, doubts are cast over John’s character, his honesty is questioned, his relationship with Helen is hidden, concealed and he alone knows it. The appearance of Helen upsets John’s life. His wife and cook threaten to quit and shadows of divorce looms large over his relationship with his wife. The plot for a new story remained ‘‘unclear’’ for a long time. It is only in the end, that John can visualise an excellent plot in its perfection. Moreover, the ghost and apparitions are always believed to remain concealed, relegated to shady and dark areas. The appearance of Helen from darkness and retreat to darkness highlights the relevance of the title.

"] ]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>The Rise of Nationalism in Europe - MCQs</title>
		<link>http://nxtclass.cu.cc/x/his/the-rise-of-nationalism-in-europe-mcqs/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 27 Feb 2012 13:40:54 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>admin</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://nxtclass.cu.cc/?page_id=335</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<strong><span style="color: #000000;">Q1. French Revolution personified which female figure?</span></strong>

Ans: <span style="color: #ff0000;">Liberty</span>

<strong>Q2. What did Liberty bear in her hand?</strong>

Ans. <span style="color: #ff0000;">In one hand she beards the torch of enlightenment and in one the Charter of the Rights of Man.</span>

<strong>Q3. The state in which the majority of its citizens, and not only its ruler, came to develop a sense of common identity and shared history or descent is known as:</strong>

Ans: <span style="color: #ff0000;">Nation-State</span>

<strong>Q4. When the French Revolution did begin?</strong>

Ans: <span style="color: #ff0000;">1789</span>

<strong>Q5. The club formed by the students and other members of educated middle classes began to known as:</strong>

Ans: <span style="color: #ff0000;">Jacobin Club</span>

<strong>Q6. By what name is Civil Code of 1804 known as?</strong>

Ans: <span style="color: #ff0000;">Napoleonic Code</span>

<strong>Q6. The Habsburg Empire ruled over which state?</strong>

Ans.<span style="color: #ff0000;"> Austria-Hungary</span>

<strong>Q7. In Galicia, the aristocracy spoke which language?</strong>

Ans: <span style="color: #ff0000;">Polish</span>

<strong>Q8. The terms ‘liberalism’ is derived from which word?</strong>

Ans: <span style="color: #ff0000;">Latin word, <em>liber</em></span>

<strong>Q9. ‘Right to Vote’ was exclusively granted to which group of people?</strong>

Ans: <span style="color: #ff0000;">Property owning men</span>

<strong>Q10. What is <em>elle?</em></strong>

Ans: <span style="color: #ff0000;">Mean of measurement</span>

<strong>Q11.Who was the representatives of the European power?</strong>

Ans: <span style="color: #ff0000;">Britain, Prussia, Russia and Austria</span>

<strong>Q12. Who was Duke Metternich?</strong>

Ans: <span style="color: #ff0000;">An Austrian Chancellor</span>

<strong>Q13. The congress was hosted by whom?</strong>

Ans: <span style="color: #ff0000;">An Austrian Chancellor Duke Metternich</span>

<strong>Q14. Where was Giuseppe Mazzini born?</strong>

Ans: <span style="color: #ff0000;">Genoa</span>

<strong>Q15. Who described Mazzini as ‘the most dangerous enemy of our social order’?</strong>

Ans: <span style="color: #ff0000;">Giuseppe Mazzini</span>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
