	<item>
		<title>Periodic Classification of Elements</title>
		<link>http://nxtclass.cu.cc/x/chem/periodic-classification-of-elements/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 01 Mar 2012 07:24:22 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>admin</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://nxtclass.cu.cc/?page_id=404</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<div class="accordion-group">
<div class="accordion-heading"><a class="accordion-toggle" href="#summary" data-toggle="collapse">Summary</a></div>
<div id="summary" class="accordion-body collapse">
<strong>Need and Why?</strong>
<ol type="i">
	<li>Helps study chemistry of elements systematically.</li>
	<li>Need not remember the properties of all elements seperately but only those of groups and periods.</li>
	<li>Helps understand the gradual change of properties.</li>
	<li>Helps understand relationship between different classes of elements.</li>
</ol>
<strong>Early classifications:-</strong>
<ul>
	<li>On basis on Metals or Non Metals:-</li>
</ul>
<p style="padding-left: 30px;">Shortcomings-</p>

<blockquote>
<blockquote>
<ol>
	<li>too general,</li>
	<li>could not explain the metallic properties of some non metals.</li>
</ol>
</blockquote>
</blockquote>
<ul>
	<li>On Basis of Valency:-</li>
</ul>
<p style="padding-left: 30px;">Shortcomings:-</p>

<blockquote>
<blockquote>
<ol>
	<li>could not explain the variable valency of single element.</li>
	<li>Elements with same valency have different properties.</li>
</ol>
</blockquote>
</blockquote>
<strong>Dobereiner's Triads (By J. Dobereiner):-</strong>
<ul>
	<li>Proposed in 1817.</li>
	<li>3 elements were grouped together according to their atomic mass. The atomic mass of the middle element is approximately equal to the average of the masses of the extreme elements of the groups.</li>
	<li>There is gradation in properties of elements of these triads. eg:-</li>
</ul>
<ol>
	<li>Li &lt; Na &lt; K : in respect of displacing H from H<sub>2</sub>O.</li>
	<li>Cl &gt; Br &gt; I : in respect of displacing each other from their compounds.</li>
	<li>Ca &lt; Sr &lt; Ba : in respect of displacing H from H<sub>2</sub>O.</li>
</ol>
<ul>
	<li>Thus, the middle element of a triad has an intermediate atomic mass and is properties lie between those elements.</li>
	<li>Shortcomings:- All elements cannot be classified.</li>
	<li>Property Explored:- Relation between atomic mass and properties of elements.</li>
</ul>
<strong>Newland's Law of Octaves (By John Newland):-</strong>
<ul>
	<li>Proposed in 1866.</li>
	<li>Newland's Law of Octaves:- When elements are arranged in the order of their increasing atomic masses, the properties of every eighth element is a repetition of the first one.</li>
	<li>Shortcomings:-</li>
</ul>
<blockquote>
<ol>
	<li>Was applicable only till Calcium as after that every 8th element was not similar to the first one.</li>
	<li>Several elements were discovered that did not fit into the Newland's Law of Octaves.</li>
	<li>To fit elements in the table two elements (Co &amp; Ni)were put in 1 slot in a column of unlike elements(Cl, F, Br and I).</li>
	<li>Iron (Fe) which resembles Co and Ni in properties, was placed far from them.</li>
</ol>
</blockquote>
<ul>
	<li>Dobereiner's triads also exist in Newland's Classification of elements.</li>
</ul>
<strong>Mendeleev's Periodic Table (The Original Periodic Table):-</strong>
<ul>
	<li>Mendeleev's Periodic Law:- Proposed in 1869, this law states that properties of elements are dependent on their atomic mass and this dependence is periodic.</li>
	<li>Periodic Table:- Devised in 1869, it was arranged in order of increasing atomic mass. Some places were left for unknown elements, eg.- Scandium; Noble gases later added as a separate column at the end of 19th Century.</li>
</ul>
<ul>
	<li>Main Features:-</li>
<ol type="a">
	<li><strong>Groups and Subgroups </strong>are the columns in the periodic table represented by Roman Numeral I-VIII.</li>
	<li>Each group is <strong>divided in two subgroups</strong>, A &amp; B which are single columned.</li>
	<li><strong>Group VIII B contains 3 sets</strong> of elements each: Fe, Co, Ni.</li>
	<li><strong>Group VIII A has Noble gases</strong>.</li>
	<li>Elements in any subgroup resemble each other.</li>
	<li>Elements of <strong>Subgroup A don't resemble those in Subgroup B</strong>.</li>
	<li><strong>Periods</strong> are the rows which comprise of the entire range of elements after which properties repeat. Represented by Arabic numerals 1-7.</li>
</ol>
	<li>Usefulness:-</li>
</ul>
<blockquote>
<ol>
	<li><strong>Valency</strong>:- Elements in a group have the same valency, that changes gradually in a period.</li>
<ul>
	<li>In respect to H -&gt; Rises from 1 to 4 and then falls 4 to 1 gradually moving from left to right.</li>
	<li>In respect to O -&gt; Maximum valency is the same as the group number.</li>
</ul>
	<li>Correction of atomic mass:- Atomic mass of an element is found out by formula: atomic mass = equivalent mass x valency.</li>
</ol>
</blockquote>
</div>
</div>
<div class="accordion-group">
<div class="accordion-heading"><a class="accordion-toggle" href="#eq" data-toggle="collapse">Extra Questions</a></div>
<div id="eq" class="accordion-body collapse">
</div>
</div>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>404</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2012-03-01 12:54:22</wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt>2012-03-01 07:24:22</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>periodic-classification-of-elements</wp:post_name>
		<wp:status>publish</wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>223</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>
		<wp:post_type>page</wp:post_type>
		<wp:post_password></wp:post_password>
		<wp:is_sticky>0</wp:is_sticky>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_wp_page_template</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[default]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_edit_last</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[3]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
	</item>
	<item>
		<title>Patol Babu, Film Star</title>
		<link>http://nxtclass.cu.cc/x/eng/patol-babu/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 06 Mar 2012 15:12:52 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>rupesh</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://nxtclass.cu.cc/?page_id=479</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[[introduction text="

Satyajit Ray, one of the grand masters of the world cinema, was a good story writer. Most of his stories were meant for teenagers. In 'Patol Babu, Film Star', he underlines the idea that no role in a film is minor or insignificant. The actor must do his job with perfection and dedication just as Patol Babu does while enacting the role of a pedestrian.

"]

[story text="

Patol Babu was recommended by his neighbor, Nishikanto Ghosh, for a role in a film. It was a pleasant surprise for him. He was already 52-year-nonentity. Years ago he was a theatre actor and was quite popular. But that was a thing of a remote past. As he was without work, he needed money badly. so he accepted the role, though it was not very significant. He was, of course, quite hopeful and excited, though his wife was not. On the set, He wanted to know his lines which he was supposed to speak. On his persistence he was handed over a slip of paper.On it was written just one word 'oh!'. He was told that he was to act as an absent-minded pedestrian who would utter 'oh!'. When he would collide with an actor walking in a hurry on the pavement.

Patol Babu was disappointed. At one time he decided to leave. Then suddenly he was reminded the words of his mentor, Mr. Pakrashi, who used to say that no actor should reject a part thinking it beneath his dignity to do so. 'Each word in a play is like a fruit in a tree.' Mr. Pakrashi once remarked. So Patol Babu went to a secluded place and rehearsed saying 'oh' in many ways and discovered several possibilities. The shot was ready. The director gave Patol Babu a moustache, which suited him well. On Patol Babu's own suggestion he was handed over a newspaper, which he would pretend to be reading while walking on a pavement. Patol Babu was able to do his role with perfection. Everybody seemed to be satisfied. Patol Babu felt deep satisfaction. He did not wait for payment and left for home. The meagre payment which he was to receive seemed to be nothing before the intense satisfaction he had to got while doing his job. He needed money, but he did not bother. He was truly a 'strange follow'.

"]

[character text="

<strong>Patol Babu:</strong>

Patol Babu, the protagonist, is a 52-year-old bald man. He is diligent, sincere and hard working. Once he was a popular theatre actor. He is talented and imaginative. He enacts his minor role in a film with perfection. He needs money badly as he is out of work, and yet is not money-minded. Without getting his payment for his role,he comes back with the feeling that he has done his job perfectly well. He is modest as well as humble.

<strong>Baren Mullick:</strong>

Baren Mullick is director of three hit films. He seems to be quite meticulous and hard working. He has an uncanny ability to judge somebody and something quickly and accurately. Patol Babu appreciates his giving him a moustache which suits him very well. Mullick is quite receptive. He agrees to Babu's suggestion of having a newspaper to pretend reading it in the scene. He knows his job well.

"]

[theme text="

The theme of the story is that money is nothing in comparison with the inner satisfaction one gets from a job well done. This is what Patol Babu reveals at the end. Though he was in need of money, he leaves home without getting the payment for his role. He is satisfied that he has done his job well. Moreover, the story brings home the idea that no role or the dialogue in a film or the stage is insignificant. A good actor can leave indelible impression doing a minor role or even uttering no word.

"]

[title text="

The title of the story is quite adaptive. It is justified as the whole story is about the protagonist Patol Babu. It begins with and ends on his story as a film actor. No other character is important as he is. The story brings about all the essential traits of his personality.

"]

[saq text="

<strong>1. What do you think of Patol Babu's passion for stage ?</strong>

Ans: About thirty years ago Patol Babu used to act on the stage. He was very popular as an actor. His name has appeared on handbills on many occasions. There was on time when people bought tickets especially to see him.

<strong>2. Patol Babu had to change many jobs. Why ?</strong>

Ans: Patol Babu had to change many jobs for several reasons. He was once retrenched due to the war. He opened a variety of shops which he could not run pr0fitably. He left a job in a Bengali firm because of the high-headedness of his boss. At present he was looking for the job in the scrap iron firm.

<strong>3.What was the role Patol Babu asked to do ?</strong>

Ans: It was the minor role of pedestrian. He was to act as an absent-minded person who would collide with a hero walking in haste on the pavement.

<strong>4. What disgusted Patol Babu about his role ? What was he reminded of ?</strong>

Ans: Patol Babu was disgusted with his role as it had only one-word sound, no dialogue. He was reminded of the words his stage mentor that one should never reject a part, however small it is.

<strong>5. 'Each word spoken in the play is like a fruit in the tree ?' Explain.</strong>

Ans: The words spoken by Mr. Prakashi meant that each word which an actor utters can be made significant, and is significant. It is the actor's delivery of the word that makes a word come alive.

<strong>6. 'That's odd-the man hadn't been paid yet. What a strange fellow!' Who i the man refered to here, and why ?</strong>

Ans: The man referred to here is Patol Babu who had gone away without taking the money for his role. He acted in the way because he felt that what was important was the inner satisfaction and not a bit of money he would get for his role.

<strong>7. Patol Babu needed money. Why do he then leave without accepting the money for his role ?</strong>

Ans: Patol Babu knew that he would get fifteen or twenty rupees which was nothing before the intense satisfaction he had got doing his job with perfection.

<strong>8. What impression do you form of Baren Mullick ?</strong>

Ans: Baren Mullick, the director of the film, knew his job. He had the ability to understand somebody or something quickly and accurately.

<strong>9. 'Counting the chickens again before they're hatched, are you ?' What does it tell you of Patol Babu ?</strong>

Ans: The statement of Patol Babu's wife reveals that Patol Babu is in the hadit of day-dreaming. He is not practical and wordly-wise.

<strong>10. What is message of the story ?</strong>

Ans: The message of the story is that nothing is insignificant in the world. it is the way we take that makes it significant or insignificant. A job done with perfection gives intense satisfaction, far more valued then any amount of money.

<strong>11. Who was Nishikanto Babu and what proposal did he bring for Patol Babu?</strong>

Ans :   Nishikanto Babu was Patol Babu’s neighbour and he brought a film offer for Patol Babu. Nishikanto’s rela- tive, Naresh Dutt was looking for someone like Patol Babu for his film and Nishikanto had suggested Patol’s name.

<strong>12. This kind of offer was ‘beyond his wildest dreams’. Why?</strong>

Ans :   Patol Babu was already 52 years old and virtually unknown, in the field of acting. So he was pleasantly sur- prised that a nonentity like him had received a film offer. Moreover he was very modest in his bearing and for quite sometime had nurtured such kind of dreams.

<strong>13. What kind of fame had Patol Babu achieved in ‘Jatras’?</strong>

Ans :   At some time in his life,  Patol Babu had a real passion for the stage. He had been simply obssessed. ‘In the Jatras’ he was very well-known and always in demand. His name appeared in handbills many times and people bought tickets specially to see him perform.

<strong>14. What desperate efforts were made by Patol Babu to earn a decent living?</strong>

Ans :   Initially Patol Babu had a job in a railway factory. In 1934, he was offered higher salary as a clerk in a fa- mous company. Later he shifted to Calcutta and soon lost his job due to war. He tried his hard at a  variety store which only  lasted for  5  years.  He worked  in a  Bengali firm, then as an insurance agent but nothing lasted.

<strong>15. What details of the role were furnished by Naresh Dutt, the film’s director, to Patol Babu?</strong>

Ans :   Patol Babu was supposed to enact the role of a pedestrian  who  is  absent-minded  and  short-tempered. There were some dialogues also according to Naresh Dutt and it was supposed to be a proper speaking part.

<strong>16. Describe the scene outside the Faraday House briefly.</strong>

Ans :  A big crowd had already gathered outside the building. A bus was carrying the equipment, There were cameras, stands, crowds of people everywhere. Most of the people were busy carrying the equipment, carting it here and there.

<strong>17. Why was Patol Babu particular about getting his dialogues in advance?</strong>

Ans :  Patol Babu was a perfectionist. He wished to practice his dialogues beforehand so that he does not make a spectacle of himself infront of the lead actors. He was too enthusiastic and didn’t wish to make any mistake in his performance.

<strong>18. 'Patol Babu glanced at the paper... and found a sudden throbbing in his head. The heat was unbearable.' Why did this happen?</strong>

Ans :   Patol Babu  found that he had to speak just one word, that too a monosyllable ‘Oh!’ He had been promised a proper speaking part and after a long wait and great expectation, he felt too depressed to see his small role. He felt cheated and quite demoralised.

<strong>19. What kind of practice did Patol Babu do?</strong>

Ans :   Patol Babu  practiced speaking  ‘Oh!’ a  thousand times.  He tried  to  give it  a  different  inflection,  add  all kinds of emotions and styles to this word. He practiced his body language, how he would act during collision with the hero, how he would fling his arms, how his body would crouch in pain and surprise.

<strong>20. What justification is rendered by Sasanko regarding Patol Babu’s speaking role?</strong>

Ans :   Sasanko was a very clever and tactful person. He told Patol Babu that he had a regular speaking part and he was indeed very lucky to get such a part in Baren Mullick’s film. Most of the people had only crowd scenes and even the lead actor had no lines to speak that day.

<strong>21. Why did Patol Babu disappear before collecting his payment?</strong>

Ans :   Patol Babu was happy at his performance because he felt that he had done his best. But he was crestfallen at the indifferent behaviour of the film people. So he felt that no money could compensate for his great efforts and the hard work he had put in. He had been simply exhausted after the long wait and hard work he had put in. Now the reward of twenty rupees looked too meagre and insufficient.

"]

[laq text="

<strong>1. Patol Babu reached home and was overcome with mixed feelings of happiness for a good performance but disappointment for being sidelined with such a speaking role. He writes a diary entry in this state of mind. Write the diary for him.</strong>

Ans : Dear Diary,

It was a day of mixed emotions, happiness and disappointment packed together. I had gone to Faraday House with great expectations and imagine I was asked to utter just ‘oh’! How I died an instant death? All my hopes and aspirations were dashed to pieces. But still I kept my cool. I remembered the advice of my mentor and perfected every bit of my role. Almost everyone, even the hero Chanchal Kumar praised my good work. But the mechanical, inhuman nature of the film-folk hurt me when the time came to collect my twenty rupees, I could not remain there. No money could measure my hard-work and dedication. I know even twenty rupees are needed at home but I felt they were not a worthy remuneration. I hope I am right! God alone knows!

Patol Babu

<strong>2. Naresh Dutt, the director, was surprised to find Patol Babu missing. He had seen Patol Babu’s meticulous nature and eye for minute details. No one ever went away without taking the money. Despite his busy schedule, Naresh Dutt couldn’t forget Patol Babu. He found out the details of Patol Babu’s hard work from other people around. He writes a letter to his friend regarding the hardwork some insignificant people put in and yet their contribution goes unacknowledged. Write the letter for him.</strong>

Ans :
Service Lane,
ABC City
5 Sept. 2010
Dear Mohan,

In our busy lives we seldom notice exceptional people who look quite ordinary. I wish to recount such an incident to you when I had hired a man, who was 52 years old named Patol Babu for a minuscule role. He just had to utter one word ‘oh’! I was told later by my staff and other people that Patol Babu, after the initial disappointment, had practiced that word in all different kind of ways. He gave a superb performance but we were too busy in other technicalities and looking after lead actors to notice it. I was amazed to discover to note that he did not want to collect his money. Maybe we have erred in some way. I am sure we undermined his capability. Nevertheless I will go home personally and try to make amends and talk to him. That will really ease my guilt. Will share the rest with you later.

Your friend,
Naresh Dutt

<strong>3. Give a character sketch of Patol Babu giving evidence from the text.</strong>

Ans : Patol Babu was a modest, talented and timid man. He was an artist at heart — emotional, talented but too prone to being hurt. He was full of dramatic skills and could deliver powerful dialogues. He had been a great hit, doing theatre for ‘jatras’ and people specially flocked to see him. He was a perfectionist and packed in a very powerful performance for his minuscule role. His Oh! had modulation of voice, body language and great dramatic skills. He was most emotional and felt really hurt to see the neglect in the eyes of the director. Patol babu is an ideal artist who is not wordly wise and a dreamer who is not practical.

"]

[ncert text="

<center><strong>Short</strong></center><strong>1. What was the news that Nishikanto Ghosh gave Patol Babu ?</strong>

Ans: Nishikanto Ghoshtold Patol Babu that his brother-in-law was looking for an actor for a scene in a film- fiftyish, short and bald-headed. He thought that the role would suit him and so he had recommended his name to his brother-in-law.

<strong>2. How did Patol Babu react ? Why ?</strong>

Ans: Patol Babu reacted positively. He agreed to do the role for the film because he had acted on the stage about thirty years ago. He had no reason to say 'no' to such a good offer

<strong>3. Why had Patol Babu lost his first job in Calcutta ?</strong>

Ans:Patol Babu was quite happy and satisfied with his job with Hudson and Kimberley i Calcutta. He had to lose his job because of sudden retrenchment in his office due to war.

<strong>4.How does Patol Babu reconcile to the dialogue given to him ?</strong>

Ans: At first Patol Babu is not happy with the one word dialogue given to hom. Then he is reminded of the words of his stage mentor, Gogon Prakashi, that each word spoken in a play is important. He himself discovers that the word 'oh' to be spoken by him carries different shades of meaning. So he gets reconciled to his dialogue.

<strong>5. Who was Prakashi ? How do his words help Patol Babu in enacting his role ?</strong>

Ans: Mr. Prakashi was Ptol Babu's mentor when he was a stage actor. His words helped patol babu to enact his role well because he had told him that no role in play is minor of insignificant.

<strong>6. How do we know that Patol Babu was a meticulous man ?</strong>

Ans: Patol Babu was meticulous man, He rehersed speaking his one-word dialogue repeatedly. He even wanted to rehearse a small role. Then it was on his suggestion that he was given a newspaper so that the scene came off quite realistically.

<strong>7. Why did Mr Mullick turn down Patol Babu’s request for a rehearsal ?</strong>

Ans: Mr. Mullick turned down Patol Babu's request for a rehearsal because the sun could be clouded at any moment. He wanted the scene to be filmed in sunlight.

<strong>8. What were the special touches that Patol Babu gave to his role to make it more authentic ?</strong>

Ans: In order to make his role more authentic, Patol Babu took apaper in the hand topretend that he was reading it when the 'collision' took place. He uttered the word 'oh' mixing fifty parts of anguish with twenty-five of surprise and twenty-fiv of irritation.

<center><strong>Long</strong></center><strong>1. 'I hope the part calls for some dialogue?' Who says this? Why does he /she ask this question?</strong>

Ans: These lines are said by Patol Babu.  He had been a stage actor for many years before work forced him to come to Calcutta.  He was a very passionate actor; in fact he was obsessed with acting.  There was a time when people would buy tickets just to see him perform.

After many years, Patol Babu was offered a role in a film. He was both surprised and happy to receive this offer.  He enquired about his role so that he could rehearse for it. He was told that his role was that of a pedestrian. He wanted to know if the role had any dialogues because he was very keen to show off his acting prowess.

<strong>2. 'Were these people pulling his legs? Was the whole thing a gigantic hoax? </strong><strong>A meek, harmless man like him, and they had to drag him into the middle of the city to make a laughing stock out of him. How could anyone be so cruel?' Why does </strong><strong>Patol Babu have these thoughts?</strong>

Ans: The reason for Patol Babu having such kind of thoughts was that the dialogue that he was given shocked him. It was for the first time that Patol Babu has got an opportunity to act in a film. Till now he had acted on the stage. He was very excited. He reaches the shooting site at the designated time. After watching the film shoot for sometime, he asked for his dialogue so that he could memorise and rehearse it.

All he had to do was to collide with the hero and utter “oh”. He was very disappointed. He expected a small role with some dialogues but here he just had to utter a monosyllable. Patol Babu was a very good actor and he thought that by giving him such an insignificant role they had made a mockery of him and his acting skills.

<strong>3. Patol Babu is an amateur actor for whom walk-on part in a movie turns into an ultimate challenge. Discuss.</strong>

Ans: Patol Babu is initially very disappointed because of the small role he had been given.  Then he is reminded of his mentor’s words that “however small a part, never consider it beneath your dignity to accept it”.Motivated by these words, Patol Babu decides to rehearse his part before the final shoot. He chooses a reclusive spot to practice. As he practices, he realises that a monosyllabic exclamation could be said in different ways and carried different meanings. He also rehearsed how he would react physically when the collision took place- he would twist his face in pain, fling his arms, and crouch to show pain and surprise. He really worked hard at his part and performed it to perfection.

<strong>4. Do you agree with the statement that Patol Babu is a practical man who comes to terms with whatever life has to offer? Give reasons for your answer.</strong>

Ans: Patol Babu had a passion for acting. In fact, there was a time when people used to buy tickets just to watch him. But he left all this and moved to Calcutta from Kanchrapara because he was offered a job with a better salary. In Calcutta, he gave up his plans of starting a club in his neighbourhood and dabbled in various jobs to make his ends meet. When an acting offer came by, he readily agreed to do it. Though he was initially disturbed by the triviality of the role, he performed the part to perfection without taking any payment for it. Patol Babu believed it was not about whether the role that an actor plays is major or minor, rather performance of the actor mattered the most. Thus, we can say that Patol Babu was a practical man who accepted whatever came his way.

<strong>5. Why does Patol Babu walk away before he can be paid for his role? What does this reveal about his character?</strong>

Ans: Patol Babu executed his part to perfection. However, he wondered whether the immense effort he had put in to enact a small role would be appreciated by everybody or not. The film unit usually got hold of some people, made them do their parts and paid them a small amount.  They were not bothered about the quality of performance.

Although Patol Babu performed a small role, he felt that taking money for it would be trivialising his performance. He was a true actor for whom creative satisfaction was foremost and not money.

<strong>6. Do you think making a movie is an easy job? Discuss with reference to the story.</strong>

Ans: The story, <em>Patol Babu, Film Star</em>, describes a film shoot. Filmmaking is a long and tedious process. Every scene has to be rehearsed many times before it is finally shot. Plenty of heavy equipments and expensive cameras are used. Film actors have to shoot in extreme weather conditions, sometimes in front of large crowds. The noise and extreme weather can, at times, distract an actor. The production unit has to see minor details, arrange for actors for small roles, and arrange for props. In short making a film is a combined effort of many people.

"] ]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>

		<wp:post_parent>217</wp:post_parent>

		<wp:post_type>page</wp:post_type>

	<item>
		<title>Virtually True</title>
		<link>http://nxtclass.cu.cc/x/eng/virtually-true/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 07 Mar 2012 08:25:05 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>rupesh</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://nxtclass.cu.cc/?page_id=553</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<div id="accordion" class="accordion">
<div class="accordion-group">
<div class="accordion-heading"><a class="accordion-toggle" href="#introduction" data-parent="accordion" data-toggle="collapse">Introduction</a></div>
<div id="introduction" class="accordion-body collapse">

Paul Stewart (1955-) has written a number of popular books for children. Among his best-known books are 'The Edge Chronicles', 'The Free Lance Novels' and 'The Far Flung Adventure Series'. In this story 'Virtually True' he imagines the human memory enters that of a computer, and that it is possible to influence human mind through the manipulation of psycho-drive games on the computer. He proposes a remote possibility in the realm of fiction.

</div>
</div>
<div id="accordion" class="accordion">
<div class="accordion-group">
<div class="accordion-heading"><a class="accordion-toggle" href="#story" data-parent="accordion" data-toggle="collapse">Story</a></div>
<div id="story" class="accordion-body collapse">

Sbestian Shultz, a 14 year-old schoolboy, was travelling in a car which met with an accident and he went into a coma. He was playing a psyco-drive game on his laptop. His head struck against the laptop and his computer, as Michel, the narrator believed , saved his memory.

Michael was surprised to find identify between the real Shultz and the Shultz of his video-games. He recalled receiving messages form Shultz on his screen to rescue him. In order to to rescue him, he played four games in all. In the first game Wildwest, he and Shultz tried to evade Black-Eyed Jed, the fastest gun in the world. A gunshot hit the Shultz and he could not be saved. The game was over. In Dragonquest, too, Shultz could not be saved as Michel's sword proved ineffective. In Jailbreak, Shultz and Michel were chased by furious guards and ferocious dogs. Shultz slipped from the staircase. Only in Warzone Michel was able to save Shultz by pulling him into the helicopter.

Strangely, this rescue of the Shultz in the world of games got related to the rescue of the real Shultz from his coma. Shultz proved the doctors wrong and had a miraculous escape from the death. Michel got a note of thanks from real Shultz for saving his life, and suggested a meeting soon. Both knew that ' By reliving the accident, something wonderful had happened. "Michel thought that everything he had described was "true-virtually !".

</div>
</div>
<div id="accordion" class="accordion">
<div class="accordion-group">
<div class="accordion-heading"><a class="accordion-toggle" href="#characters" data-parent="accordion" data-toggle="collapse">Characters</a></div>
<div id="characters" class="accordion-body collapse">

<strong>Michel:
</strong>Like his father, Michael has passion for computer games. He seems to spend a lot of time on playing 3-D and psycho-drive games . He is quite skillful in playing games. It is through games that we lernt that he is bold, aggressive and helpful. He plays the games not to hit the jackpot but to rescue Shultz in distress.

<strong>Sebestian Shultz:
</strong>The real Sebestian Shultz is the 14 year-old schoolboy. He goes into a coma. he comes out of it the moment his memory is restored by Michael's manipulating the game he used to play. The fictional Shultz is adventurous, clever and schemy, though he fails again and again . He does not give in and encourages Michel to 'rescue' him.

</div>
</div>
<div id="accordion" class="accordion">
<div class="accordion-group">
<div class="accordion-heading"><a class="accordion-toggle" href="#theme" data-parent="accordion" data-toggle="collapse">Theme</a></div>
<div id="theme" class="accordion-body collapse">

This is a futuristic story which is only true. It brings home the that there can be interaction between two advanced intelligences on the earth- the human intelligence and the computer intelligence. It shows how Michael by manipulating a psycho-drive game on his computer- which has saved the memory of Sebastian Shultz at the time of his going into the coma in an accident- helps save Shultz who miraculously awakes from his coma.

</div>
</div>
<div id="accordion" class="accordion">
<div class="accordion-group">
<div class="accordion-heading"><a class="accordion-toggle" href="#title" data-parent="accordion" data-toggle="collapse">Title</a></div>
<div id="title" class="accordion-body collapse">

The title of the story 'Virtually True' is quite adaptive. The story of Shultz who goes into a coma has a miraculous recovery. His memory is saved on a computer at the time when his head bangs against the computer. Somehow a boy Michael gets hold of the same disk and plays the games in which the same boy (Shultz) is a character. He rescues him and thus helps the real Shultz awake from his coma. Thus, the story seems to be quite fictive, but theoretically speaking, it is virtually true. Who knows human and computer intelligences may begin to interact one day in future ?

</div>
</div>
<div id="accordion" class="accordion">
<div class="accordion-group">
<div class="accordion-heading"><a class="accordion-toggle" href="#saq" data-parent="accordion" data-toggle="collapse">Short Answer Questions</a></div>
<div id="saq" class="accordion-body collapse">

<strong>1. How did Michael notice the story of Sebastian Shultz?</strong>
Ans : Sitting in the train, Michael saw a big lady, reading a newspaper. There was a story with a title ‘Miracle Recovery’. It was written that Sebastian Shultz, a 14-year- old boy from London, had been badly injured in a motor accident and had gone into a coma. His mother hoped that one day her son would be well and only a miracle could save him.

<strong>2. While playing Wildwest, Michael found himself in a particular role. What was it and how did he behave in the game?</strong>
Ans : To his surprise, Michael was playing the role of a Sheriff and he burst into a saloon. Everyone was surprised by his entry. He had some fizzy kind of drink when a black-eyed Jed, the fastest gun, called him out of the saloon. As he was going, a second Sheriff appeared and he did not look like other characters. His movement was also not like a computer image. His entry made the game more complicated.

<strong>3. Who was Black-Eyed Jed and what did he convey to the Sheriff?</strong>
Ans : Michael was the Sheriff in the game ‘WILDWEST’. When he was enjoying a drink in the saloon, he was challenged by a Black-eyed Jed the fastest gun in the west. He wanted to confront the Sheriff. So he was called out of the saloon.

<strong>4. What was the objective of the second game called Dragon quest? In what role did Sebastian appear in it?</strong>
Ans : The aim of the game DRAGON QUEST was simple. It was to rescue fair princess Aurora from the wicked dragon and to collect the wicked dragon’s treasure. Sebastian appeared in the form of a knight and even Michael was also supposed to be a knight.

<strong>5. How did the two knights try to escape from the castle of the dragon? Were they successful?</strong>
Ans : Both the knights were chased by the wicked dragon. They ran across the battlements down a spiral staircase and through a secret passage on the other side of the tapestry. The dragon was near them and they could feel his fiery breath. Both of them, then decided to try going through the dungeons which was their only hope.

<strong>6. Point out the desperation in Sebastian’s message to Michael. What did he tell Michael to do?</strong>
Ans : When Michael was unable to save Sebastian in the earlier two games, Sebastian’s message becomes desperate. He earnestly requests Michael not to give up, otherwise he would remain stuck up whereever he was. So he wishes him luck and tells him to try the game ‘JAILBREAK’.

<strong>7. How did Michael and Sebastian escape from Jail in Jailbreak? Why was Sebastian injured in this escape?</strong>
Ans : Sebastian was Michael’s cell-mate in the game ‘JAILBREAK’. They use a skeleton swipe card to open the cell-door and run away. Sirens wail, guards run after them, fiery dogs howl and chase them. Both of them run upstairs but they are chased. Before Michael can do something, Sebastian falls down on the concrete below.

<strong>8. How did Michael connect Sebastian’s recovery from coma with the result of his last game?</strong>
Ans : Apparently, at the time of an accident, Sebastian was using his laptop to play one of the psycho-drive games. He had been plugged into the computer and when he banged his head, the computer saved his memory as its own. Those games were stolen when Sebastian was in the hospital. These games were sold in the market and Michael bought them from a Computer Fair.

<strong>9. What were the contents of Sebastian’s last message? Why did Sebastian thank Michael?</strong>
Ans : The last message was full of heart felt emotions. Sebastian thanked Michael for saving his life and working so hard in every game to rescue him. Sebastian extends an invitation to meet him and a wishes him well. He also tells Michael to keep these psycho-drive games as he deserveds to keep them.

</div>
</div>
<div id="accordion" class="accordion">
<div class="accordion-group">
<div class="accordion-heading"><a class="accordion-toggle" href="#laq" data-parent="accordion" data-toggle="collapse">Long Answer Questions</a></div>
<div id="laq" class="accordion-body collapse">

<strong>1. Sebastian Shultz writes his diary on his miraculous escape from going into oblivion—as doctors call it coma. Write this for him.</strong>

Ans : Dear Diary,
Sometimes life takes a strange turn and things that you had heard or read about become true. Virtual lives and realities take concrete shape. I just remember that I was crazy for those psycho-drive games and loved playing WARZONE, DRAGON QUEST etc. My last memory is when my head banged in the accident. After that I have no memory but a very distinct feeling of playing some games. I have read my report in the newspaper, how I had gone into a coma. It can only be called a miracle that I was playing games with another boy called Michael, which I discovered later strange! So very strange.
Sebastian.

<strong>2. Write a brief character sketch of Michael, giving his outstanding qualities that led him to save Sebastian’s life.</strong>

Ans : Michael was of Sebastian’s age and he loved adventure, war, pursuits, fights, confrontation and violent games. Like other children of his age he was a computer freak and was really fascinated by psycho-drive games that make one forget the reality and one plays character like a Sheriff, a prisoner, knight etc. Michael is also very kindhearted and tried his best to rescue Sebastian. He was intelligent enough to understand the objective of each game. By strange luck he got connected to Sebastian, whom he had never seen but proved his perseverance and determination in rescuing him from his coma. Michael is a young child but mature beyond his years.

<strong>3. Sebastian sends an e-mail to Michael on his recovery thanking him for all that he had done. Complete it for him.</strong>

Ans : Date : 15 Sept, 2010
From : <a href="mailto:sebastian@hotmail.com">sebastian@hotmail.com</a>
To : <a href="mailto:michael@gmail.com">michael@gmail.com</a>
Subject : Thank you note
Dear Michael,
I cannot thank you enough for being the miracle to save my life. Your perseverance, tenacity and determination prove that you are extraordinary. No wonder you saved my life and now I have fully recovered from my coma. I hope to meet you soon.
Lots of love.
Sebastian

</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>

	</item>
	<item>
		<title>Ozymandias</title>
		<link>http://nxtclass.cu.cc/x/eng/ozymandias/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 07 Mar 2012 15:07:10 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>rupesh</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://nxtclass.cu.cc/?page_id=573</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[[abpoet text="

Shelley was born in 1792 at Field Place, near Horsham, Sussex. He was the son of wealthy land owner who later on succeeded to a baronetcy. He went to study at University College, Oxford and there his chosen studies were metaphysics and religion and soon he developed a passion for reforming the world. Shelly is the great English romantic poet. He is regarded as one of the best lyrical poets. His poems like the 'Old to the West Wind', 'The Cloud', 'To a Skylark', 'To Night' reflect his lyrical quality in abundance. In these poems we notice the spirit of nature which appeals to us in the wind and the cloud, the sunset and the moonrise seems to have possessed him.

His poetry reflects two moods. In one he is the violent reformer, seeking to overthrow the present institutions. In another mood, he is like a wanderer following a vague but beautiful vision.

"]

[abpoem text='

In this sonnet, Shelley illustrates the vanity of human greatness and failure of all attempts to immortalise human achievements. Ozymandias was a great Egyptian king. A life-like statue of the king was made to immortalise him. But now the statue lies broken and disfigured in a desert.

A traveller from Egypt sees two huge and trunk less legs of a statue in a desert. Near them lies , half-buried, the broken face of the statue. On this face one can see the expression of arrogance and a sense of authority which have been skillfully depicted by the sculptor on the statue. On the pedestal the following words are inscribed:

"My name is Ozymandias and I am a great king. Look at the great deeds that I have accomplished and which nobody can equal." The broken statue is surrounded by a vast desert.

The poem reflects that human glory and prompt are everlasting. Time works havoc with monuments and statues. Thus. the poet strikes a moral in a suggestive manner.

']

[title text="

The title of the poem is named after the great Egyptian king named Ozymandias. The title is very adaptive because the whole poem revolves around his character. The poet illustrates Ozymandias' vanity, arrogance and pride and his failure to immortalise himself by getting his statue made. Time has played havoc with his statue and it lies broken and disfigured in a desert. The poem reflects that human glory and promp are nort everlasting. The poet strikes a moral by depicting the futility of Ozymandias' vanity and pride.

"]

[pphrase text="

<strong>1 – 8 lines – (I met a traveller .................... that fed)</strong>

The speaker recalls having met a traveller from an ancient land who told him a story about the ruins of a state in the desert of his native country. The traveller said that two vast legs of stone stand without a body and near this, a massive crumbling and broken stone-head lies, which is half sunk in the sand. The statue has a bitter and cruel expression of ‘sneer and cold command’ and this indicates that the sculptor had understood the passions of his subject really well. It was obvious that the statue was of a man who sneered with contempt for those who were weaker than himself, yet fed his people because of something in his heart.

<strong>9 – 14 lines – (My name ......................... far away)</strong>

On the pedestal of the statue these words are inscribed, ‘‘My name is Ozymandias, I am the king of kings. If anyone wishes to know how great I am, then let him surpass any of my works. Around the decaying ruin of the statue, nothing remains, only the ‘lone’ and level sands’ which stretch out around it, far away.

"]

[col url="ld" title="Literary Devices in the poem" text="

<strong>Alliteration</strong>
<ul>
	<li>sneer of cold command</li>
	<li>survive, stamped on these lifeless things</li>
	<li>the loan and level sands stretch far away</li>
	<li>boundless and bare</li>
</ul>
<strong>Sonnet</strong>
<ul>
	<li>The poem 'Ozymandias' is in the form of a sonnet.</li>
</ul>
<strong>Rhyme Scheme</strong>
<ul>
	<li>Its rhyme-scheme consist of an octave (a set of eight lines) and a seset (a set of six lines)</li>
	<li>The rhyme-scheme dosen't follow any of the recognised pattern, and some of rhymes are faulty (for instance, stone and frown; appear and despair).</li>
</ul>
<strong>Pictures</strong>
<ol>
	<li>Near them, on the sand
Half-sunk, a shattered visage lies, whose frown
And wrinkled lip and sneer of cold command</li>
	<li>Nothing besides remains.
Round the decay  Of that colossal wreck, boundless and bare
The love and level sands stretch far away</li>
</ol>
<ul>
	<li>In the first picture, the poet paints the picture of the broken statue, a huge wreck, the face of which still wears a frown and the sneer of cold command.</li>
	<li>In the second picture, the poet paints the picture of the love and level desert, boundless and bare, stretching far away.</li>
</ul>
<strong>Synecdoche</strong>
<ul>
	<li>It is the figure of the speech in which substitution of part stands for the whole or the whole stands for the part.</li>
	<li>e.g. the hand that mock'd them.</li>
</ul>
"]

[saq text="

<strong>1. Whome did the narrator meet ? Where ?</strong>

Ans: The narrator met a traveller from an ancient country i.e. Egypt.

<strong>2. What did the traveller tell the narrator ?</strong>

Ans: The traveller told the narrator that he had see two huge and trunkless legs os a statue in the desert. There lay the broken face of a statue near them. One could see the expression of arrogance and a sense of authority which had been skilfully depicted on the statue by the sculptor.

<strong>3. What was inscribed on the pedestal ?</strong>

Ans: The inscription on the pedestal was: 'My name is Ozymandias, king of kings Look on my works, ye Mighty, and despair.'

<strong>4. What did the sculptor observe about the king ?</strong>

Ans: The sculptor observed that the king was proud, vain and arrogant. He had the sense of authority.

<strong>5. How did the sculptor capture king's feelings ?</strong>

Ans: The sculptor made a statue of the king on which he skilfully depicted the expression of haughtiness and a sense of authority.

<strong>6.Explain the touch of melancholy about the poem.</strong>

Ans: There is a touch of melancholy about the poem because it makes us reflect over the vanity of human wishes and the faliure of all our efforts to keep our memory alive for ever.

<strong>7. Explain the two pictures painted by the poet in his poem.</strong>

Ans: The first picture refers to the broken statue. Though it lies broken in the desert, it carries the frown and the sneer cold command of the king on its face. The second picture refers to the lone and level desert which is boundless and bare, stretching far away.

<strong>8.  What is the theme of the poem ?</strong>

Ans: The poet wants to cnvey that humn glory and promp are not everlasting. Ozymandias, the king of Egypt, got his statue made in order to immortalise himself. But the time played havoc with his statue and noe it lies broken and disfigured in a desert. Thus, the poet illustrates the vanity of human greatness and the failure of all attempts to immortalize human grandure.

<strong>9.What impression do you form of and sculptor ?</strong>

Ans: The sculptor appears to be very competent, skillful and observant. He observed that the king was vain, roud, arrogant and had a sense of authority. So he captured the feelings and passion of the king in statue of the king very skilfully.

<strong>10. How did the poet come to know about the broken statue of Ozymandias?</strong>

Ans : The poet was told the story of Ozymandias by a speaker who had met a traveller from an ancient land. The story and the condition of Ozymandias’ statue is conveyed by word of mouth. This adds a tinge of obscurity and mystery to the statue.

<strong>11. In what condition was the statue found?</strong>

Ans : The statue of Ozymandias was found in a distant desert. The head of the statue was broken and nearby two vast legs of stone stand without a body. The head is half sunk in the sand. The statue has a bitter and cruel expression of command and power.

<strong>12. Who had written the inscription on the pedestal below the statue ? What did it indicate?</strong>

Ans : On the pedestal of the statue the words inscribed were, “My name is Ozymandias, I am the king of kings. If anyone wishes to know how great I am, then let him surpass my works.” These words indicate the arrogance, conceit and arrogance of the king. The king appeared to sneer at people who were weak and helpless.

<strong>13. Describe the surroundings of the statue of Ozymandias?</strong>

Ans : The broken statue of Ozymandias was surrounded by vast stretches of sand and loneliness of deserts. These ruins prove that the king’s work and civilisation has crumbled to dust. Nothing lasts forever, and loneliness, desertion convey a feeling of crumbling under the cruel knife of time.

<strong>14. Do you believe Ozymandias was justified in persisting in the belief of his supremacy? Why/ Why not?</strong>

Ans : Ozymandias was cruel, dominating and arrogant. He was too conceited and looked down upon the weak and helpless. He believed that he was the mightiest. But his challange was ironically disproved by time itself. All his achievements, fame, empire were razed to the ground. Fate and time make a crockery of all this. So his boast could never be justified.

"]

[laq text="

<strong>1. Give the chacacter-sketch of king Ozymandias as depicted in the poem.</strong>

Ans : King Ozymandias considered himself to be the king of kings. He ruled over his empire with a firm hand. He fed his subjects but regarded them as inferior. He was boastful of his power and considered himself to be above all. He believed that no one will ever be able to equal his achievements. He considered himself to be blessed with extraordinary powers. The king was so intoxicated with power and passion that the welfare of his people was never his consideration. He believed himself to be above law and destiny. Ironically his statue and the surroundings proved just the opposite. He believed himself to be even greater than other kings — the Emperor of all.

<strong>2. Suppose by a miracle Ozymandias visits planet Earth and comes across his statue in that dilapidated state. He is dejected and awakens to the realisation of a life frittered away for materialistic and political gains. In a state of regret he pens down his thoughts in the form of a diary entry. Write the diary for him.</strong>

Ans : Dear Diary,

Traversing over the desert, I was dumbfounded with great shock when I discovered that my statue was lying broken, without head and body, in an eroded state. Imagine my reaction. I had considered myself above all, I was the greatest, the mightiest, and I believed that the coming generations would worship or pay respect to my statue. The condition of my statue pained me. All my achievements, my confidence in my power was razed to the ground. There were sands and loneliness around. No one seemed to remember my greatness. May be I was wrong. I should have devoted my life to welfare, looked after my people with compassion and care, maybe then the fate of my statue would have been different.  Ozymandias.

<strong>3. After reading the poem, what is the lesson ingrained in it for the rest of mankind? Discuss.</strong>

Ans : Power, position, pelf should be used for the welfare of mankind. History may record one’s territorial achievements but if one wins the hearts of people, then that is real victory. One must command respect and not demand it. Many times sages and saints are respected more than mighty kings. So one must never misuse power and might. Time is a great leveller. So glorious deeds should be committed to get respect from posterity. Shelley also demonstrates the fact that art and language long outlive the other legacies of power. Real power is winning hearts and not in ruling the weak and the needy.

"]

[ncert text="

<center><strong>Short</strong></center><strong>1. ‘‘The hand that mocked them, and the heart that fed’’. Whose hand and heart has the poet referred to in this line?</strong>

Ans: The poet refers to the sculptor's hand which reproduced the king's feelings on stone. Then the poet refers to the king's heart ehich nourished those feelings and passion in his heart.

<strong>2. ‘‘My name is Ozymandias, king of kings’’. Why does Ozymandias refer to himself as ‘king of kings’ ? What quality of the king is revealed through this statement ?</strong>

Ans: Ozymandias refers himself as king of kings because he thinks that he is the gretest king of all kings due to his great deeds, achievements and victories. Nobody can become as great as he is. The vanity, pride and arrogance of the king are revealed through this statement.

<strong>3. ‘‘Look on my works, ye Mighty, and despair ’’! Who is Ozymandias referring to when he speaks of ye Mighty? Why should they despair?</strong>

Ans: Ozymandias is referring to other poweful and brave warriors. He wants to tell them that they should hive up all hopes of equalling him. He is great and powerful because of his great deeds, achievements and victories. The should despair because they cannot become as great and powerful as he is.

<strong>4. Bring out the Irony in the poem.</strong>

Ans: Ozymandias, the great king of Egypt, gets his statue made in order to immortalise himself. He excepts that his name will live till posterity. But time plays havoc with the statue. The statue lies broken and disfigures and orrounded with barren desert. His expectation is belied and thus the whole situation is ironical.

<strong>5. “Nothing beside remains”. What does the narrator mean when he says these words?</strong>

Ans: The narrator means to say that the statue lies broken and disfiured and is suroounded by barren desert. There is nothing else to be seen near the statue. A vast, desolate and barren dessert sorrounds the remains of the huge statue which lies broken.

<strong>6. What is your impression of Ozymandias as a king ?</strong>

Ans: After reading the poem, we come to know that Ozymandias is proud, vain and arrogant king. At the sme time we find that is mighty and brave king because of his great deeds, achievements and victories. No othr king could ho[e to equall him and become as great and powerful as he was.

<strong>7. What message is conveyed in the poem ‘‘Ozymandias’’?</strong>

Ans: In this poem the poet wants to convey the vanity of human greatness and the faliure of all attempts to immortalise human gandure. Ozymandias, the great king of Egypt, gets his statue made in order to immortalise himself.  But the time plays havoc eith the statue and now it lies broken and disfigured in a desert. Thus, the poet conveys a message that human gloy and peomp are not everlasting.

<center><strong>Long</strong></center><strong>1. Discuss the poetic style of the poem, ‘‘Ozymandias’’.</strong>

Ans: Ozymandias written in 1817 is a very masterful sonnet by Shelley. It is written in iambic pentameter and was an unusual rhyme-scheme. The poem interlinks the octave by gradually replacing old rhymes with new ones in the form of ABABACDCEDEFEF.

This sonnet is Shelly’s brilliant rendering of the story of a powerful king. Framing the sonnet as a story told to the speaker by ‘‘a traveller from an antique land’’, enables Shelley to add another level of obscurity to Ozymandia’s position with regard to the reader. Rather than seeing the statue with our own eyes, we hear it from someone who has heard from another source, so and so forth. Thus the ancient king is rendered less commanding. The distancing of the narrative serves to undermine his power over us, like the passage of time. Shelley gradually reconstructs the figure of the king. First we see the ‘‘vast trunkless legs,’’ then the ‘shattered visage’’ and, then the inscription. The expression on the king’s face, then we are introduced to the king’s people of his time. The kingdom is now imaginatively complete and we are introduced to the proud boast of the king. With this the poet demolishes our imaginary picture of the king, with centuries of ruin and bare sands between it and us. Basically the poet is devoted to a single metaphor throughout the poem – the shattered ruined statue in the desert waste land with its arrogant and passionate face.

"] ]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Snake</title>
		<link>http://nxtclass.cu.cc/x/eng/snake/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 07 Mar 2012 17:38:52 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>rupesh</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://nxtclass.cu.cc/?page_id=593</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[[abpoet text="

D.H. Lawrence (1885-1930) is primarily one of the greatest English novelists of 20th century. He is widely known for his novels like 'Sons and Lovers' and 'Two Women'. His novels reflect the complexity of relationship between man and women. But he is a versatile writer. Besides being a novelist he is a story writer, critic, poet and painter.

"]

[abpoem text="

The poem Snake by D.H.Lawrence, is more or less like an ode, celebrating the encounter of the poet with a snake that came as a trespasser into his domain for water. The poem starts by indicating the event, the time and the atmosphere. The snake to quench its thirst went to the poet's “water – trough” on a “hot day”. Also, the poet who is the owner of the water trough, came for the same purpose in his pyjamas to avoid the “heat”. The poet is said to be coming from his “strange – scented shade” with a “pitcher” in his hand. On reaching the water trough, the poet, as a matter of courtesy, chose to wait to enable the snake to drink as it was the first to reach there. The snake whose origin was from a fissure in the earth-wall, slither slowly with its “yellow-brown”, “soft belly” to the “edge of the stone trough”. The snake rested its “throat upon the stone bottom” and started drinking softly through its mouth into “his slack long body”. The poet referred himself as a “second comer” waiting for the snake to finish drinking. The poet, while waiting, observed its mode of drinking and described it as that of cattle. The poet could hear the “voice” of his education and resolved to kill the snake, “for in Sicily the black, black snakes are innocent, the gold are venomous”. This implies that the poet believed that black snakes are harmless while gold snakes are harmful, making a reference to "Sicilian July" and "Etna smoking", which are both historical events. The poet's inner voice prompted him to kill the snake but was restrained believing that the snake “should seek hospitality” in him. For sparing the snake, the poet felt so honoured. The snake having shown hospitality “drank enough and lifted its head” “and flickered his tongue”. Having quenched its thirst, the snake turned around slowly with it's long curved body towards it's origin. The snake moved in slowly into the hole without any fear. Suddenly, the poet looked around and put down his pitcher, “picked up clumsy log and threw it at the water-trough”. This was done to kill the snake but it did not. The snake hearing the “clatter” hastily moved in its remaining body “into the black hole”. At the disappearance of the snake, the poet regretted his action immediately and blamed himself for acting the way he did. He put the blame on the voice of his education to have lured him into it and feared not to pay for his negative action like the sailor that killed “the albatross”. The poet after regretting wished the snake could come back for him to crown it like a king but believed it would never do so and sees it “like a king in exile”. The poet concluded by feeling that he had to make an amendment.

"]

[title text="

The title of the poem snake is appropriate because the poet describes his encounter with the snake who had come to drink water from his water trough on a hot day. The snake came there to quench his thirst. He came out from the crack and trailed over the edge of the stone trough. He rested his throat upon the stone bottom and sipped the water into his slack long body.

The poet thought of killing the snake. However, he instinctively began to like the snake. Then the poet describes his responses to the presence of the snake at his water trough. After drinking water to his satisfaction, the snake licked his lips and drew into his hole. The poet picked up a long and hurled at the snake. The snake twisted violently and then vanished into the hole.

The poet regretted his action and felt guilty. He realised that he had to atone for his mean action. The whole poem revolves around the snake. Therefore the title is adaptive.

"]

[pphrase text="

<strong>A snake ......................................................... stone bottom.</strong>

A snake visited the poet’s water trough on a very hot afternoon to quench his thirst. The water trough was under the shade of a red flowery tree, which let out a strange kind of scent. The poet who had also gone to the trough to fill water in a pitcher waited for the snake to finish, since he had come to the trough earlier than the poet. The poet is very particular regarding protocol, so he believes that he must wait for his turn to take the water.

<strong>And ware ............................................................... waiting.</strong>

The snake had come from a crack in the wall made of earth and from the darkness, it comes out to the edge of the water trough. The snake is yellow brown in colour, with a soft belly, it must have come slowly to the water trough. The snake rested his throat upon the stone-bottom and sipped the water into his slack long body. The snake did this very silently. The poet waited for his turn, since he had come after the snake’s arrival.

<strong>He lifted ....................................................... Etna smoking.</strong>

The snake relaxed in between and lifted his head after drinking water like cattle. He appeared to be looking in the poet’s direction and the poet could see his forked tongue. The snake appeared to think for a few moments then again bent down and drank some more water. The snake was brown like the earth and he had come out from the burning bottom of the earth. It was a very very hot day in Sicily, in the month of July, and Mount Etna, an active volcano, was also sending out fumes, making the day hotter.

<strong>The voice ............................................................... him off.</strong>

Education and social conventions make the poet think that the golden brown snakes were poisonous, so they must be killed. Black snakes were considered harmless but brown ones were dangerous. As a brave man, he must undertake the task of killing the snake.

<strong>But must ............................................................ this earth?</strong>

The poet makes a frank confession that he really liked the snake so he didn’t feel like killing him. The snake had come like a guest to drink water from the poet’s water trough and was going to depart in a peaceful and satisfied manner. The snake would eventually go back in the hot and scorching bowels of the earth.

<strong>Was it .............................................................. secret earth.</strong>

The voices of education in the poet told him that it was the fear of the snake that made him refrain from killing him. However the poet felt that though he was quite afraid of the snake, he did actually feel honoured that a snake had come to seek his hospitality from the deep recesses of the earth

<strong>He drank .............................................................. wall-face.</strong>

The snake drank enough water to his satisfaction and then raised his head dreamily and flickered his tongue. He seemed to lick his lips. He looked around like a God and then slowly proceeded to curve round and move away from the water trough. The snake moved so slowly as if he was dreaming or was asleep and again went back to climb the wall with the crack, from where he had come.

<strong>And as he ......................................................... was turned.</strong>

The snake put his head inside the crack and then easing his shoulders, entered deep inside the hole. The poet disliked the retreat of the snake into the dark and deep horrible hole. A sort of protest rose in the poet’s mind and he became quite agitated, the moment the snake turned his back.

<strong>I looked ...................................................... with fascination.</strong>

The poet put down his pitcher, picked up a log and hurled it at the snake. The snake twisted violently and with great agility vanished into the hole in the wall. The tail of the snake which had been left also vanished in great haste like lightning. The snake had entered the crack in the wall. All the poet could do was to stare with fascination at the manner in which the snake had disappeared.

<strong>And immediately .................................................... education.</strong>

The poet was full of guilt and felt that he must atone for the meanness of his action of throwing a log at the snake. He really hated himself for such a mean act and cursed the voice of education that had always taught him to kill snakes, without any reason. Just as the Ancient Mariner had killed the albatross without any reason the poet had also tried to strike at the snake for no reason. He really prayed and wished for the snake to come back.

<strong>And I thought .................................................. crowned again.</strong>

The poet felt that the snake had behaved in a dignified manner like a king and he was also the king of the underworld. The snake was inside the earth, like a king in exile. Now enough was enough and the poet wished to give due respect to the snake that was befitting of a king.

<strong>And so, ............................................................. a pettiness.</strong>

The poet deeply regretted his mean act of trying to kill the snake. He had really missed the chance of treating the snake well, of giving him respect that is due to a king. Now he would have to make amends for his petty and mean act.

"]

[col url="ld" title="Literary Devices in the Poem" text="

<strong>Similes</strong>
<ul>
	<li>He lifted his head from his drinking, as cattle do</li>
	<li>And flickered his tongue like a forked neighed on the air</li>
	<li>seemed to me again like the king</li>
</ul>
<strong>Alliteration</strong>
<ul>
	<li>strange-scented shade, slackness soft-bellied down, sipped with his straight mouth burning bowels</li>
	<li>and departed peaceful, pacified</li>
	<li>the dark door of the secrete earth</li>
	<li>to lick his lips</li>
	<li>broken bank of my wall-face</li>
	<li>he put his head into that dread hole</li>
	<li>put down my pitcher</li>
	<li>softly drank through his straight gums, into his slack long body, silently</li>
</ul>
<strong>Repetition</strong>
<ul>
	<li>On a hot, Hot day</li>
	<li>I was afraid, I was most afraid</li>
	<li>And slowly, very slowly</li>
	<li>like a king, like a king in exile</li>
</ul>
<strong>Onomatopoeia</strong>
<ul>
	<li>He sipped with his straight mouth</li>
</ul>
"]

[saq text="

<strong>1. Why does the poet repeat “hot”, “must wait” twice? What purpose does it serve?</strong>

Ans : These words are used repeatedly because the poet wishes to emphasise on them. ‘Hot’ means very hot as there are many reasons like the month of July, Etna volcano etc. ‘Must wait’ means compulsion. The poet believes that anyone who comes first, must be served first.

<strong>2. From where had the snake emerged? What do you think was the reason for the snake to come out in the open?</strong>

Ans : The snake had come out from the crack in the wall. It was very hot and scorching inside due to July month, active volcano etc. The snake wanted to drink water and satisfy his thirst.

<strong>3. Describe the relaxed manner in which the snake makes his way to the water trough and the manner in which he drinks water.</strong>

Ans : The movement of the snake is described as ‘slack’ ‘soft-bellied’, most relaxed and unhurried. He appeared out of a crack in the wall and very languorously stretched himself and slow crawled to the edge of the water-trough. One reason could be that he had not seen the poet.

<strong>4. Why is the snake compared to cattle?</strong>

Ans : The relaxed manner in which the snake drinks water reminds the poet of cattle. Even the cattle drink water, then look up, muse a moment and continue. The snake also behaves similarly.

<strong>5. How were the poet’s beliefs regarding snakes conditioned by society?</strong>

Ans : Society ingrains certain preconceived notions in our mind and due to that we don’t judge situations by instinct — The poet was fascinated by the snake. He appreciated the snake’s majestic and harmless nature but the earlier instincts drilled in him by society force him to strike at the snake. He had been taught to kill snakes.

<strong>6. Explain – ‘And depart peaceful, pacified and thankless’.</strong>

Ans : The snake appeared to be pacified and satisfied, for he had taken water generously. He was not the harmless kind, neither had the poet given him any reason, so there was no confrontation. The poet believes that the snake has no reason to thank the poet for a natural resource like water which is God’s gift for all.

<strong>7. Why does the poet feel honoured by the presence of the snake?</strong>

Ans : The poet feels obliged that the snake had come all the way from the inner depths of the earth to his water trough and this was a kind of honour. Moreover the snake is so regal and majestic in his bearing that the poet feels honoured to have him as his guest.

<strong>8. The poet is too impressed with the majestic manner in which the snake conducts himself. What comparisons does the poet make to highlight this behaviour of the snake?</strong>

Ans : The manner in which the snake drinks water is like the cattle. He appears to muse a bit, drink with intervals. The snake is called ‘Lord of life’ because life and death is in his hands. He is also compared to ‘a king’ for his majestic style and when he quickly disappears he is compared to lightening.

<strong>9. Why did the poet have a sudden urge to hit the snake? Do you think he was justified in trying to hit the snake, when its back was turned?</strong>

Ans : When the snake’s back is turned, the ‘voices of education’ that were troubling the poet, overtake him. He hits the snake with a stick which was quite unjustified. The snake had not troubled the poet and one must behave with one’s instincts than preconceived notions.

<strong>10. Why did the poet despise himself? Mention the three words that he uses to describe his action.</strong>

Ans : The poet feels very guilty of trying to hit at the snake. He calls his act ‘mean’ ‘petty’ and feels like making amends. The poet believes that he must compensate for his unreasonable and undignified act. He uses the words ‘to expiate’, which express his feelings.

"]

[laq text="

<strong>1. Describe the manner in which the snake arrived and departed.</strong>

Ans : The snake had come from the crack in the wall made of earth, from the darkness, from the scorching inside portion of the earth. The snake did not feel the threat of the poet’s presence, so its movement is very languid, very relaxed and unhurried. It stretched its long and slack body, drank water with great spells of flavour and enjoyment. It licked its lips, it mused and put his head on the edge of the water-trough. Its departure was exactly the opposite, quick, clumsy, abrupt like the speed of lightening.

<strong>2. You have read the poem ‘snake’ and you understand the dilemma faced by the poet. Suppose you had been there instead of the poet, how would you have behaved? Write a letter to your friends Prateek, expressing this situation and how did you resolve it.</strong>

Ans : 92, G.P. Road  ABC City  12 July, 2010  Dear Prateek,  I wish to recount a strange experience that I underwent recently. One day as I had come to fill my pitcher with water from a open water-trough, I saw a snake drinking water there. My first instinct was fright and then I felt like killing him, because that is what we do generally. Nevertheless, I hid behind the door and watched the snake. The snake was very relaxed, very slack and had great style of moving about. After drinking water, the snake went back into the hole. I felt happy that I had not hit him. I am happy I followed the voice of my instincts.  Mohan.

<strong>3. Write a short note on the literary devices used by the poet. Discuss their effectiveness in the context of the poem.</strong>

Ans : D.H. Lawrence has made use of many literary devices liberally. He begins the poem by using some words expressions repeatedly, to reinforce and highlight certain ideas. There is a great use of alliteration in words like ‘slackness’, ‘soft-bellied’ etc. Lot of similes have been used to describe the snake. The snake is compared to ‘cattle’ ‘like a king’ ‘Lord’ etc. The snake disappears into the hole with the speed of lightening. Moreover the snake is symbolic of some strange forces and it represents power and sophistication that impress the poet.

"] ]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>

		<wp:post_parent>217</wp:post_parent>
