	</item>
	<item>
		<title>The Rime of the Ancient Mariner</title>
		<link>http://nxtclass.cu.cc/x/eng/rime-of-the-ancient-mariner/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 07 Mar 2012 19:30:09 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>rupesh</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://nxtclass.cu.cc/?page_id=605</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[[abpoet text="

S.T. Coleridge is one of the well-known Romantic English poets. He is known for his poem like 'Kubla Khan', 'The Rime of the Ancient Mariner' and 'Christabel' and his critical work Biographia Literaria. In 'The Rime of the Ancient Mariner', he highlights the Christian concept of sin, punishment and redemption through the story of the old Mariner who happens to kill an albatross.

"]

[abpoem text="

The old mariner with grey beard and the 'glittering eye' stops one of the three persons going to attend the wedding feast. The man is in no mood to listen to his story. He is a close relative of the bridegroom. But transfixed by the 'gilttering eye' of the mariner, he has to sit on a stone and listen to his story.

The mariner begins to narrate his story. when they started there voyage, they were given a warm send off. The weather remained good for some days. Then a storm arose. It drove the ship towards the icy south pole. There were snow and mist. It was very cold. Then the albatross- a huge sea bird- appeared. It followed the ship. A wind helped the ship come out of the cold region. The albatross followed behind the ship. It was considered to be the bird of the good omen. Then one day the old mariner shot the bird dead with his crossbow without and reason.

The weather remained fine. The crew who condemned their mate for killing the bird t first changed their opinion about the bird. They thought that it was the bird that had brought the mist. There shipmate was right in killing it, believed.

When the ship reached the equator the breeze stopped. It was very hot. The ship was stranded. There was no water to drink. The sea was muddy. Strange creatures fell in and out of the water around the ship.

Some sailors dreamed of the spirit that wanted to take revenge for the killing of the albatross. without the wind and the water the sailors felt silent. They could not speak. The held the old mariner responsible for their sufferings. They snatched the cross from the old mariners neck, and hung the dead albatross in its place. The dead albatross around his neck was the constant reminder of his guilt.

"]

[title text="

The us of word 'Rime' suggests that the poem is a rhyming poem, a song. 'Ancient' not only indicates that it is the poem about an old sailor (seaman), but also the "strange, far off time" the action of the poem apparently belongs to. It containd the story of his sin, punishment and redemption the Ancient Mariner narrates to the Wedding-Guest. Thus, the title of the poem is very adaptive and suggestive.

"]

[pphrase text="

<strong>Lines 1-4 :</strong>

An Ancient Mariner stopped one of three guests invited to a wedding. The guest was bewitched by the long grey beard and the shining eyes of the Mariner. But he did not like being interrupted and asked the Mariner why he had been detained.

<strong>Lines 5-8 :</strong>

He said that the doors of bridegroom's house were wide open. He being colsely related to the bridegroom was expected to reach there very soon. The guests had been already arrived there. The feast was set. The noise of merry-making could be haerd even from where they were standing.

<strong>Lines 9-12 :</strong>

The Mariner

"]

[col url="ld" title="Literary Devices in the poem" text="

<strong>Alliteration</strong>
<ol>
	<li>the furrow followed free</li>
	<li>down dropt the breeze</li>
</ol>
<strong>Smilie</strong>
<ol>
	<li>like a three years' child</li>
	<li>red as a rose</li>
	<li>like noises in a swound</li>
	<li>like witch's oil</li>
</ol>
<strong>Metaphor</strong>
<ol>
	<li>snowy clifts</li>
	<li>the very deep</li>
</ol>
<strong>Repetation</strong>
<ol>
	<li>glittering eye</li>
	<li>water, water</li>
</ol>
<strong>Personification</strong>
<ol>
	<li>Sun</li>
	<li>Storm Blast</li>
</ol>
"]

[theme text="

The poem primarily deal with Christianity and the supernatural. The old mariner impulsively shoots the Albatross and this act results in his agony and misery. Coleridge believed that the seeds of creations and destruction are interlinked. Destruction leads to new creation. The loss of mariner's ship and his own former self leads to his regeneration.

Some of the other major themes the poem deals with are:
<ul>
	<li>Sin and Redemption:- Man commits sin, but if he repents his wrongdoings and performs penance he gets salvation. The protagonist, the Ancient Mariner, who commits a sin by killing the albatross, is hounded by guilt in the form of a strange supernatural phenomena. During this terrifying experience, her has a change of heart and repents his wrong doing. He pays penalty by traveling around the world to tell his tale to strangers.</li>
	<li>Respect for Nature:- Human beings should respect all of God's creations , including the Albatross. In doing so, people indicate their respect for the Creator himself.</li>
</ul>
"]

[col url="idea" title="Central Idea of the Poem" text=" The poem portrays man's intense quest for salvation from the sins he has committed during the journey of his existence. The albatross symbolises Christianity, stating 'as if it had been a Christian Soul.' The presence of the Albatross was significant to the crew in terms of spirituality which manifests itself through signs both symbolic and mysterious. "]

[laq text="

<strong>1. The poem is a narration about crime and punishment. Elucidate.</strong>

Ans. The ship gets stuck in the South Pole region until an Albatross appears out of the mist. It is hailed in God's name. It leads the ship and its crew out of the threatening realm of ice and snow. The Ancient Mariner kills it impulsively. This act arouses the wrath of the supernatural forces. The winds drive the ship to uncharted waters where it is becalmed. The sailors believe the Albatross's spirit is following them and causing them agony. Tormented by thirst, the members of the crew punish the Ancient Mariner by hanging the Albatross around his neck as a constant reminder of his wicked act.

<strong>2. What was the initial reaction of the Sailors when the old mariner shot the albatross? Why did they later approve of his act?</strong>

Ans. Initially, the sailors blamed the old mariner for killing the bird whose arrival had made the ice break apart, allowing them to steer out of the freezing cold. Later, when the weather became pleasant, they approved of its killing as it had brought mist and snow."] ]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>605</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2012-03-08 01:00:09</wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt>2012-03-07 19:30:09</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>rime-of-the-ancient-mariner</wp:post_name>

		<wp:post_parent>217</wp:post_parent>

		<wp:post_type>page</wp:post_type>
		<wp:post_password></wp:post_password>

		</wp:postmeta>

		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_flattr_post_category</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[text]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>

	<item>
		<title>Julius Caesar</title>
		<link>http://nxtclass.cu.cc/x/eng/julius-caesar/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 08 Mar 2012 15:57:25 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>rupesh</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://nxtclass.cu.cc/?page_id=623</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<div class="accordion-group">
<div class="accordion-heading"><a class="accordion-toggle" href="#abplaywright" data-parent="accordion" data-toggle="collapse">About the Playwright</a></div>
<div id="abplaywright" class="accordion-body collapse">
<p>William Shakespeare was born on April 23, 1564 at Stratford-upon-Avon in Warwickshire. He was the son of John and Mary Shakespeare. John Shakespeare was proposed businessman. When seven years of age, Shakespeare was admitted into a Grammar School. At the age of fourteen. Shakespeare has to leave school. In 1528, when Shakespeare was eighteen, he married Anne Hathaway. In 1587, he left Stratford for London. It appears that he was in considerable strains for want of money. Between 1588 and 1589, he commenced writing his great plays, the first being Loves's Labour Lost.</p>
<p>In 1597, at the age of thirty-three, Shakespeare returned to Stratford and bought a house there, which he called New Palace. At New Palace, he lived until his death in 1616. He was buried in Stratford Church, where his monuments is still to be seen.</p>
</div>
</div>
<div id=" The accordion" class="accordion">
<div class="accordion-group">
<div class="accordion-heading"><a class="accordion-toggle" href="#abplay" data-parent="accordion" data-toggle="collapse">About the Play</a></div>
<div id="abplay" class="accordion-body collapse">
<p>Leading scholars believe that Julius Caesar was written about 1598-99. It was the first of the three Roman plays (the other two being Antony and Cleopatra, 1608 and Coriolanus, 1610). Julius Caesar is and historical play, as it deals with the historical events that took place in ancient Rome between 44 B.C. and 42 B.C. The characters in the play, namely Julius Caesar, Marcus Brutus, Caius Cassius, Mark Antony and others are all historical persons, who actually existed in Rome. But it is important to note that a dramatist often takes liberties with history.</p>
</div>
</div>
<div class="accordion-group">
<div class="accordion-heading"><a class="accordion-toggle" href="#summary" data-parent="accordion" data-toggle="collapse">Summary</a></div>
<div id="summary" class="accordion-body collapse">
<p>Roman citizens are preparing to welcome Julius Caesar, who is returning home after having achieved victory over the sons of Pompey. The people of Rome are rejoicing and are in a holiday mood. The Tribunes do not like that people should rejoice. They are the followers of the Pompey and are Republicans. They are opposed to Caesar who they consider to be a dictator. They disperse the gathering crowds, telling them that Caesar is the enemy of the Republic which Pompey tried to strengthen. Caesar, however is too popular and powerful to be opposed by Tribunes. The triumphal procession takes place on the day of Lupercal when public games are held. Brutus and Cassius are present on the occation. Cassius begins to flatter the Brutus with intention of gaining his moral support for the conspiracy, which he is hatching. Cassius has private grudge against Caesar. He is only waiting to enlist the support of Brutus since Brutus is dearest friend of Caesar. Brutus is an ideal Republican who hates all absolute rule and dictatorship. Cassius cleverly puts into his mind the fear that Rome is in the danger of losing its freedom as a Republic. Brutus is won over this way. The group of conspirators, including Brutus and Cassius go to the senate House where Caesar is preceding. They present to himself a petition on behalf of omen Climber who has been banished by Caesar. They pray to Caesar for his recall. When Caesar turns down their requests, they stab him and kill him. Soon, the people of the Roe demand that they be satisfied with the Caesar's murder - Caesar who was deeply respected and loved by them. At the funeral of Caesar, Brutus goes into the pulpit to explain the murder. He tells the crowd that Caesar has been put to death because he was ambitious to become the king of Rome. After Brutus finishes his address, Antony is given an opportunity to speak. Antony is one of the follower of the Caesar. In his speech Antony exposes the claim of the conspirators. He incites the mob to mutiny. He also shows them Caesar's will in which Caesar has generously gifted money to every Roman citizen. The people rise up in revolt against the conspirators, burn their houses, kill some of them and force Cassius and Brutus to flee from Rome.</p>
</div>
</div>
<div id="accordion" class="accordion">
<div class="accordion-group">
<div class="accordion-heading"><a class="accordion-toggle" href="#characters" data-parent="accordion" data-toggle="collapse">Characters</a></div>
<div id="characters" class="accordion-body collapse">
<p><strong>Julius Caesar</strong><br />
Julius Caesar is the great warrior and popular ruler. he has won many battles and defeated Pompey's sons. He is worshipped by the people. He is quite fearless. He prides himself o his resolution. He remains unmoved by the request of the senators. His stubborn attitude makes many people hostile. He had no belief in superstitions, spirits and omens. He rejects the fears created by the Soothsayer. Even after his death, he continues to be a powerful force and influence. His spirit refuses to die.</p>
<p><strong>Marcus Brutus</strong><br />
Marcus Brutus holds a high position in Rome. He is much respected for his nobility and selflessness. He is a nationalist. He loves freedom and republicanism. When he is sure that his friend Caesar has become a dictator, he sides with his enemies. In fact, he is blinded by his over-confidence. This over-confidence becomes the cause of his failure, defeat and death. He makes a blunder in allowing Antony to deliver the funeral speech.</p>
<p><strong>Cassius</strong><br />
Cassius is Caesars enemy. It is who builds a conspiracy against Caesar. He is jealous of Caesar. He is practical. He knows that without the help of Brutus, the forces of conspiracy cannot win. So he does his best in seeking the support of Brutus. In spite of his weakness, he has extreme love for his country. He loves freedom. He is convinced that Caesar will become dictator and put an end to their freedom. So when he learns that Caesar is to wear the crown, he promises to himself to work against Caesar.</p>
<p><strong>Mark Antony</strong><br />
Mark Antony is firmly devoted to Caesar. When Caesar is killed, he decides to take the revenge on Caesar's enemies. He is quite cunning and scummy. At first, he befriends the conspirators. Then he turns the wave against them. His funeral speech reveals that he is a stubble orator who can play on the emotions of his listeners. He is a leisure-loving person. He is fond of play.</p>
<p><strong>Portia</strong><br />
Portia is Brutus's wife and Cato's daughter. She is worthy of sharing her husband's secrets. She is a true and honourable wife. She stands by her husbands in all her circumstances.</p>
<p><strong>The Role of Mob</strong><br />
Shakespeare has portrayed the mob mentality very realistically. When one is in the mob, he loses his own conviction, he is swayed by the collective sense of conviction. the mob in 'Julius Caesar' is depicted as headless, senseless and fickle minded. When Brutus addressed the people they are easily convinced that Caesar was ambitious. But when Antony swayed the mob with his powerful speech, the mob is ready to chase the conspirators and destroy their houses.</p>
</div>
</div>
<div class="accordion-group">
<div class="accordion-heading"><a class="accordion-toggle" href="#theme" data-parent="accordion" data-toggle="collapse">Theme</a></div>
<div id="theme" class="accordion-body collapse">
<p>One of the main themes of this play is over-confidence a a human weakness. Over-confidence makes one proud and unkind. It makes oe short-sighted and blind of one's weakness. Julius Caesar in his over-confidence ignores the pleas f his Senators. He fails to judge the pulse of the people. He fails to retain the confidence of even his close friend like Brutus. He has to pay a heavy price for this weakness. Marcus Brutus is another character who falls with a victim of over-confidence. It is in over-confidence that allows Antony to deliver a funeral speech, which turns the public against him and his associative. Over-confidence leads to his defeat and death.</p>
</div>
</div>
<div id="accordion" class="accordion">
<div class="accordion-group">
<div class="accordion-heading"><a class="accordion-toggle" href="#title" data-parent="accordion" data-toggle="collapse">Title</a></div>
<div id="title" class="accordion-body collapse">
<p>the title of the play 'Julius Caesars' is quite apt. Julius Caesar is the hero pf the play. The play is mainly about him. Even after his death, Caesar is potential force to reckon with. From the beginning to end, it is Caesar or his spirit that remains the cause of concern to others. He remains a towering figure. Without him, nothing is of interest. Therefore, the play has got an appropriate title. We cannot think of any other better title.</p>
</div>
</div>
<div id="accordion" class="accordion">
<div class="accordion-group">
<div class="accordion-heading"><a class="accordion-toggle" href="#usupernatural" data-parent="accordion" data-toggle="collapse">Use of Supernatural</a></div>
<div id="usupernatural" class="accordion-body collapse">
<ul>
<li>A legitimate dramatic device : It plays an active and significant part.</li>
<li>Frequent mention of omens : Caesar's death is presaged by numerous omens, Caesar's spirit visits Brutus, Calpurnia's dream.</li>
<li>Dramatic importance : It creates an atmosphere of horror and suspense.</li>
<li>Not something superimposed : Rather than supernatural stands for the pent-up feelings of man.li&gt;</li>
</ul>
</div>
</div>

<p>[ncert text="(a) How do the heavens ‘blaze forth’ the death of Julius Caesar?
Ans. Calpurnia sees ill-omens that predict the death of Caesar beforehand. The heavens predict the death of princes and great kings. There were fierce battles, blood rained, ghosts were seen, graves opened up, battle cries were heard. All this signaled that someone as powerful as Caesar was bound to suffer.

(b) What does Calpurnia convince Caesar of?
Ans. She convinces Caesar to avoid going to the senate. She believed that Caesar would be safe if he stays at home.

(c) Why does Calpurnia say Caesar’s ‘wisdom is consumed in confidence?’ What does it mean?
Ans. When Caesar is adamant about going to the senate, Calpurnia dissuades him. But Caesar believes that ill-omens are for the weak and not for the mighty like him. Then Calpurnia says that Caesar’s over confidence has clouded his wisdom. He was so confident that he refused to see reason nor understood the indication behind the ill omens.

(d) What was Calpurnia’s dream? How was it interpreted by Decius Brutus?
Ans. Calpurnia sees a terrifying dream in which Caesar is murdered, his statue is gushing blood and many smiling Romans are bathing their hands in his blood. Calpurnia was not superstitious but earlier in the night she had a nightmare comprising the dead man walking about. She felt that the dream was a premonition of the evil that was going to befall Caesar. So she forbids Caesar to go to the Senate. But Decius cleverly interprets it positively. He says that the vision of Romans bathing in Caesar’s blood signifies that Caesar’s spirit or influence will touch many lives; staining their handkerchieves in Caesar’s blood indicates reverence, dedication and a token of memory on part of the Romans.

(e) What arguments did Brutus and other conspirators give to justify the killing of Caesar?
Ans. Julius Caesar is an able general and a mighty conqueror who has brought great glory to Rome. It is believed by many that Caesar is too ambitious and would one day be the Roman emperor and a dictator. Jealous of Caesar’s growing power, Cassius instigates a conspiracy to murder Caesar. The conspirators were unhappy with Caesar’s obstinacy and egoistic behaviour. Cassius was jealous of Caesar’s soaring power and popularity. According to Cassius, Caesar was a tyrant who wanted to treat the Romans as slaves and that Roman liberty and democracy were under threat from Caesar. Brutus stabbed Caesar because he was an idealist and believed that ambition and tyranny should be nipped in the bud but Cassius killed Caesar because he wanted to be a part of the Roman triumvirate.

(f) Why is Decius more successful than Calpurnia in persuading Caesar?
Ans. Decius interprets Calpurnia’s dream as a fair and fortunate vision. He says that the vision of Romans bathing in Caesar’s blood signifies Caesar’s spirit or influence will increase manifold. Basically he boosts
Caesar’s ego flatters his greatness and might and makes him feel more powerful. So Caesar is happier with his version.

(g) What is the petition put before Caesar by the conspirators? How does Caesar respond to it?
Ans. The conspirators want Caesar to pardon Publius Cimber and recall the order of his banishment. Caesar refuses the request and says that his order cannot be changed and he will stick to his decision.

(h) Who says ‘Ete tu Brute’? When and why?
Ans. Caesar utters these words which mean, ‘‘you too, Brutus’‘. These are uttered when Brutus stabs Caesar and Caesar is too hurt to see that even his dear friend Brutus could resort to such treachery.

(i) In the moments following Caesar’s death, how do the conspirators proclaim to justify Caesar’s death?
Ans. The conspirators wish to justify Caesar’s death by announcing their love and loyalty to Rome. They say that Caesar was very ambitious and Romans would have become slaves under his autocratic rule. According to Brutus, Caesar was a tyrant and Roman liberty and democracy was under threat and Caesar wished to become an Emperor.

(j) What does Antony say after Caesar’s death, when he sees the body of Caesar?
Ans. Antony apologizes to Caesar’s body for being meek and gentle with his murderers. He curses the hands that killed such a noble man. He also requests them to kill him for he cannot tolerate Caesar’s death.

(k) How do Brutus and Cassius respond to Antony’s speech?
Ans. Both Brutus and Cassius request Antony not to plead for his own death. They offer him authority and good position and ask for his support in the murder of Caesar.

(l) Whom does Antony call ‘‘the choice and master spirits of this age’‘. Why?
Ans. Antony calls Brutus and Cassius the most powerful people after Caesar’s death, they have all the power. Moreover he wants to flatter their ego, to pretend that he is not against them.

(m) How do Brutus and Cassius respond to Antony’s request for giving a speech? What are the conditions imposed by them?
Ans. Cassius is very much against Antony’s idea of speech but Brutus feels that no harm can befall him and others with just a speech. Brutus says that he will give a speech first and justify Caesar’s death so there will not be a problem, if Antony delivers his speech later. Moreover Antony is had agreed to deliver the speech from the same platform and not talk against them.

(n) When he is left alone with the body of Caesar what does Antony call Brutus and others?
Ans. Antony curses the murderers and he seeks forgiveness for being polite to them. He calls them ‘butchers’ who killed the noblest of men.

(o) What prediction does Antony make regarding the future events in Rome?
Ans. Antony prophesies that Rome will be ravaged with civil war, violence and extreme blood shed will leave the earth full of dead bodies. Goddess of revenge will descend on earth with Caesar’s spirit and the stench of dead bodies will fill the earth.

(p) Who says ‘‘let him be Caesar’‘? What light does this throw on the speaker?
Ans. The 3rd citizen says this. This statement reflects on the vulnerability of the mob which believes, whatever is told to it. They say that Brutus should be put in place of Caesar, after being impressed by his speech. Later they turn towards Mark Antony and are ready to kill Brutus and others.
"]
</p></div></div></div></div>]]></content:encoded>

		</wp:postmeta>

	</item>
	<item>
		<title>Two Gentelmen of Verona</title>
		<link>http://nxtclass.cu.cc/x/eng/two-gentlemen-of-verona/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 08 Mar 2012 16:14:02 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>rupesh</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://nxtclass.cu.cc/?page_id=632</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<div id="accordion" class="accordion">
<div class="accordion-group">
<div class="accordion-heading"><a class="accordion-toggle" href="#introduction" data-toggle="collapse" data-parent="accordion">Introduction</a></div>
<div id="introduction" class="accordion-body collapse">

Born in 1896, A.J. Croni was a doctor by profession. His first novel Hatter's Castle became very popular, as a result of which he stopped practising medicine and took to writing as career. He wrote many novels and short stories. The Citadel, The Key of The Kingdom and The Spanish Gardener are his notable novels.

The title of his story 'Two Gentlemen of Verona' is taken from an early play of William Shakespeare. The story tells about the hardships faced by two sincere and selfless young boys for the treatment of their sister suffering from tuberculosis. It conveys the idea that there is a hope for humanity so long as people are willing to make sacrifices for the well-bing of others.

</div>
</div>
<div id="accordion" class="accordion">
<div class="accordion-group">
<div class="accordion-heading"><a class="accordion-toggle" href="#story" data-toggle="collapse" data-parent="accordion">Story</a></div>
<div id="story" class="accordion-body collapse">

The narrator and his companion were driving through the foothills of the Alps. Two small boys selling wild strawberries stopped their car on the outskirts of Verona. They looked quite shabby. The driver was not in favour of buying strawberries from them. The narrator's companion learned that boys were brothers. The elder, Nicola, was aged 13 while his younger brother. Jacopo, was aged 12. The narrator and his companion bought biggest basket of strawberries from the boys and drove to the city. The next morning they saw the to boys engaged in shoe shining job. The boys said that they did many things. They could even be guides to show the visitors places of interests in the town. The narrator asked them to take to Juliet's tomb. During the week of their stay in the town, the boys proved very useful to the visitors.

One night the boys were found with a bundle of unsold newspapers, ready to sell the papers when the last bus arrived. The narrator took pity on them and asked them why they were working so hard. He said that they seemed to earn adequate money, and asked why they were then spending no money on the clothes and food. Nicola said that they had some plans in their mind but did not elaborate.

Jacopo requested the narrator to carry them in his car to village Poleta, 30 kms from there. He said it would be a great favour. Nicola did not like his brother's thus troubling the narrator. the narrator readily agreed to obliged the boys. The following afternoon and his companion drove to the village. The boys went into large red-roofed villa which turned to be a hospital.

The narrator entered the hospital and met a nurse in a white uniform. The nurse took him to the room. The two boys were seemed seated at a beside of a girl of about 20. The resembled the boys. The nurse asked the narrator to enter the room and see the girl Lucia who would be pleased to meet him.

The narrator refused to introduce in the room. He wanted the nurse to tell him about the girl and the boys. The nurse told him that Lucia was the boy's sister, afflicted with tuberculosis. During the war, the bomb destroyed their home. Their father, a widower, had been killed in the early part of the war. After his death the three children came to starvation. The boys grew to hate the Germans who came to rule the city. They even joined the resistance movement. After the war was over, Lucia was found afflicted with tuberculosis. The boys admitted her in the hospital. They had been making payment regularly to the hospital.

The narrator waited outside the room. He kept quite and did not say a word in order to give the impression that boys had safely kept their secret.

</div>
</div>
<div id="accordion" class="accordion">
<div class="accordion-group">
<div class="accordion-heading"><a class="accordion-toggle" href="#characters" data-toggle="collapse" data-parent="accordion">Characters</a></div>
<div id="characters" class="accordion-body collapse">

<strong>The Boys :</strong>
The two boys in the story, Nicola and Jacopo, are the two 'gentlemen' of the Verona. Nicola, aged 13 , is the elder brother of Jacopo aged 12. Both of them are extremely sincere, devoted to self-sacrificing. They are ready to do anything to save their sister Lucia who is affected with tuberculosis. They love hard life to do all sorts of job. They shine shoes, sell fruit, hawk newspapers, conduct tourists and run errands. Yet they seemed to be contended. They are also highly self-respecting. They do not want to publicize their family problem. They keep their family secret well. They are real heroes. During the war they come to hate the Germans. They join the resistance movement for their countrie's freedom.

<strong>The Narrator :</strong>
The narrator in the story is quite sensitive, sympathetic and helpful person. Despite his driver's warning. he buys strawberries from the boys to help them. He takes pity on the shabbily dressed and nearly starved boys. He wonders why they o not spend money on clothes and food. He helps the boys in every possible ways. He is quite obliging. He carries the boys in his car to the hospital where their sister is under treatment. he is quite wise in allowing the boys to keep their secret.

</div>
</div>
<div id="accordion" class="accordion">
<div class="accordion-group">
<div class="accordion-heading"><a class="accordion-toggle" href="#title" data-toggle="collapse" data-parent="accordion">Title</a></div>
<div id="title" class="accordion-body collapse">

The title of this story from one of the early plays of Shakespeare, which focuses on the qualities of two gentlemen. In the story the two boys, Nicola and Jacopo, are the gentlemen in the true senses of the term- considerate, sympathetic, selfless, kind and gentle. The whole story focuses on theme and dramatizes their inherit qualities. Thus, the title is quite adaptive and suggestive.

</div>
</div>
<div id="accordion" class="accordion">
<div class="accordion-group">
<div class="accordion-heading"><a class="accordion-toggle" href="#theme" data-toggle="collapse" data-parent="accordion">Theme</a></div>
<div id="theme" class="accordion-body collapse">

The story deals with the idea that selfless actions bring nobility to human life. They give a promise of a greater hope for human society. By their selfless deeds and devotion the two boys in the story show that human existence has a meaning and purpose. Destructive acts like war cannot break the noble spirits.

</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>632</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2012-03-08 21:44:02</wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt>2012-03-08 16:14:02</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>two-gentlemen-of-verona</wp:post_name>
		<wp:status>publish</wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>217</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>
		<wp:post_type>page</wp:post_type>
		<wp:post_password></wp:post_password>
		<wp:is_sticky>0</wp:is_sticky>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_edit_last</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[4]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>seo_noindex</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[false]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_wp_page_template</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[default]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_flattr_post_hidden</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[0]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_flattr_post_language</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[en_GB]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_flattr_post_category</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[text]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>seo_follow</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[false]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
	</item>
	<item>
		<title>Mrs Packletide&#039;s Tiger</title>
		<link>http://nxtclass.cu.cc/x/eng/mrs-packletides-tiger/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 08 Mar 2012 18:44:44 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>rupesh</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://nxtclass.cu.cc/?page_id=669</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<div id="accordion" class="accordion">
<div class="accordion-group">
<div class="accordion-heading"><a class="accordion-toggle" href="#introduction" data-parent="accordion" data-toggle="collapse">Introduction</a></div>
<div id="introduction" class="accordion-body collapse">

Ski, the story writer, was born in 1870 and passed away in 1916. His real name was Hector Hugh Munro, a British writer. He is known for his witty and satirical stories, most of which have surprise endings.

'Mrs Packletide's Tiger' is a satire in the vanity of women who go to extremes to show their superiority over the rivals. Mrs Packletide wanted to shoot a tiger only to prove that she was no less then Loona Bimberton who had been carried miles in an aeroplane and continued to boast about it. Though she 'killed' a tiger yet she had to pay a heavy price to satisfy her vanity.

</div>
</div>
<div id="accordion" class="accordion">
<div class="accordion-group">
<div class="accordion-heading"><a class="accordion-toggle" href="#story" data-parent="accordion" data-toggle="collapse">Story</a></div>
<div id="story" class="accordion-body collapse">

Mrs Packletide wants to hog the limelight by killing a tiger. Her intention was to surprise the achievement of Loona Bimberton who had been boasting of having been carried away eleven miles in an aeroplane by an Algerian aviator. She wanted to have personally produced tiger skin. She had in her mind to host a party in honour of Loona Bimberton, with a tiger-skin rug occupying most of the foreground. She would then boast of her achievement. She also intend to present a tiger-claw brooch to Loona Bimberton on her next birthday

So she offered a thousand rupees for the risk free opportunity of shooting a tiger. People in a neighbouring village thought of earning the price money. An old lion was around, killing domestic animals. On a moonlit night a platform was constructed. A goat was tiedd at a convenient distance. Mrs Packletide with her rifle, along with her paid companion Miss Louisa Mebbin, was on the platform, ready to shoot the tiger when it came.

The tiger came and spotted the goal. It lay flat on the earth. Being very old and perhaps ill also, it wanted some rest before attacking the prey. When the tiger began to amble towards its victim, Mrs Packletide fired a shot. The tiger sprang to one side and died. The crowd of rustics present yelled with excitement . It was Louisa Mebbin who pointed out that it was the goat that had been killed by the shot and the tiger must have died of heart failure caused by the sidden report of the rifle.

Despite of this discovery Mrs Packletide received the credit of killing the tiger. A report and her picture was published in newspaper. Loons Bimberton, however, refused to look at the newspaper, declined the luncheon-party and sent a letter to thanks to Mrs Packletide for the gift of a tiger-claw brooch. Mrs Packletide had to go gift Miss Mebbin an expensive cottage to keep her secret.

</div>
</div>
<div id="accordion" class="accordion">
<div class="accordion-group">
<div class="accordion-heading"><a class="accordion-toggle" href="#characters" data-parent="accordion" data-toggle="collapse">Characters</a></div>
<div id="characters" class="accordion-body collapse">

<strong>Mrs Packletide:</strong>
Mrs Packletide is a jealous, vain and boastful women. It is just out of jealousy that she plans to kill a tiger and outsmart her rival Loona Bimberton. She wants to prove her superiority over her. She dose not mind playing any price to satisfy her vanity. Her weakness is naturally exploited by Miss Mebbin who forces her to gift her a cottage to keep her secret. She is not bold to admit that she has failed to hit and kill the tiger. She wants to hog the limelight, for which she has to pay dearly. She seems to realize her folly towards the end.

<strong>Louisa Mebbin:</strong>
Louisa Mebbin is a very cunning and money-minded person. She gets paid even for giving company to Mrs Packletide. She is quite miserly. She doesn't let go money out of her hands easily. At one point she even discourages Mrs Packletide for spending thousand rupees on killing an old tiger. When the opportunity of blackmailing Mrs Packletide comes, she strikes hard and takes an expensive cottage from her for keeping her secret.

<strong>Loona Bimberton:</strong>
Loona Bimberton is also vain and boastful in nature. She continues to talk of her areil experiences as if it were her grand achievement. She is plain jealous and declines the luncheon-party to be hosted by Mrs Packletide. She knows the real intentions of her rival.

</div>
</div>
<div id="accordion" class="accordion">
<div class="accordion-group">
<div class="accordion-heading"><a class="accordion-toggle" href="#title" data-parent="accordion" data-toggle="collapse">Title</a></div>
<div id="title" class="accordion-body collapse">

The title of the story is quite adaptive. The whole story revolves around Mrs Packletide's Tiger. The tiger which is very old and ill dies because of heart failure. However, Mrs Packletide takes the credit of 'killing' it. The tiger becomes an object of satisfying a lady's vanity.

</div>
</div>
<div id="accordion" class="accordion">
<div class="accordion-group">
<div class="accordion-heading"><a class="accordion-toggle" href="#theme" data-parent="accordion" data-toggle="collapse">Theme</a></div>
<div id="theme" class="accordion-body collapse">

The main idea of the story is that a person can go to any extreme to out smart his or her rival. The feelings of vanity get expressed in strange ways. In order to make Loona Bimberton low in her esteem Mrs Packletide plans to kill a tiger. A personally produced tiger-skin, she thinks, will prove her superiority over her rival. Ironically, she has to pay a very heavy price to do it. Vanity is undoubtedly a negative feeling and those who indulge in it repent sooner or later.

</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>सआदत अली को अवध के तख्त पर बिठाने के पीछे कर्नल का क्या मकसद था?</title>
		<link>http://nxtclass.cu.cc/%e0%a4%b8%e0%a4%86%e0%a4%a6%e0%a4%a4-%e0%a4%85%e0%a4%b2%e0%a5%80-%e0%a4%95%e0%a5%8b-%e0%a4%85%e0%a4%b5%e0%a4%a7-%e0%a4%95%e0%a5%87-%e0%a4%a4%e0%a4%96%e0%a5%8d%e0%a4%a4-%e0%a4%aa%e0%a4%b0-%e0%a4%ac/</link>

		<dc:creator>arkokoley</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://nxtclass.cu.cc/?p=71</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[सआदत अली ऐश पसंद इंसान था। कर्नल का उसे तख्त पर बिठाने का मकसद अवध की धन सम्पत्ति पर अधिकार पाना था। तख़्त पर बैठते ही उसने अंग्रेज़ों को अपनी आधी सम्पत्ति और दस लाख रूपये नगद दे दिए। इस तरह सआदत अली को गद्दी पर बैठने से अंग्रेजो लाभ ही लाभ था।]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>कंपनी के वकील का कत्ल करने के बाद वज़ीर अली ने अपनी हिफ़ाज़त कैसे की?</title>
		<link>http://nxtclass.cu.cc/%e0%a4%95%e0%a4%82%e0%a4%aa%e0%a4%a8%e0%a5%80-%e0%a4%95%e0%a5%87-%e0%a4%b5%e0%a4%95%e0%a5%80%e0%a4%b2-%e0%a4%95%e0%a4%be-%e0%a4%95%e0%a4%a4%e0%a5%8d%e0%a4%b2-%e0%a4%95%e0%a4%b0%e0%a4%a8%e0%a5%87/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 30 Jan 2012 15:32:34 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>arkokoley</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://nxtclass.cu.cc/?p=73</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<div>
<div id="tabs">
<div id="optionContent1">

कंपनी के वकील की हत्या करने के बाद वज़ीर अली आजमगढ़ भाग गया और वहाँ के नवाब से सहायता ली। नवाब ने उसे सुरक्षित घागरा तक पहुँचा दिया। तब से वह वहाँ के जंगलों में छुपा रहने लगा।

</div>
</div>
</div>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>seo_noindex</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[false]]></wp:meta_value>

	<item>
		<title>सवार के जाने के बाद कर्नल क्यों हक्का-बक्का रह गया?</title>
		<link>http://nxtclass.cu.cc/%e0%a4%b8%e0%a4%b5%e0%a4%be%e0%a4%b0-%e0%a4%95%e0%a5%87-%e0%a4%9c%e0%a4%be%e0%a4%a8%e0%a5%87-%e0%a4%95%e0%a5%87-%e0%a4%ac%e0%a4%be%e0%a4%a6-%e0%a4%95%e0%a4%b0%e0%a5%8d%e0%a4%a8%e0%a4%b2-%e0%a4%95/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 30 Jan 2012 15:37:13 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>arkokoley</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://nxtclass.cu.cc/?p=75</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[सवार, वज़ीर अली था। उसने बड़ी चतुराई से खुद को वज़ीर अली का कर्मचारी बताकर कर्नल के खेमे में जाकर उसी से कारतूस ले आया था। जाते समय कर्नल ने नाम पूछा तो <span id="26_TRN_9">उसने</span> अपना नाम वज़ीर अली बताया। वज़ीर अली को तथा उसकी बहादुरी को देखकर कर्नल हक्का-बक्का रह गया।]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>लेफ़्टीनेंट को ऐसा क्यों लगा कि कंपनी के खिलाफ़ सारे हिंदुस्तान में एक लहर दौड़ गई है?</title>
		<link>http://nxtclass.cu.cc/%e0%a4%b2%e0%a5%87%e0%a4%ab%e0%a4%bc%e0%a5%8d%e0%a4%9f%e0%a5%80%e0%a4%a8%e0%a5%87%e0%a4%82%e0%a4%9f-%e0%a4%95%e0%a5%8b-%e0%a4%90%e0%a4%b8%e0%a4%be-%e0%a4%95%e0%a5%8d%e0%a4%af%e0%a5%8b%e0%a4%82/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 30 Jan 2012 15:41:21 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>arkokoley</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://nxtclass.cu.cc/?p=77</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<div>
<div id="tabs">
<div id="optionContent1">

कर्नल ने लेफ़्टीनेंट को बताया कि कंपनी के खिलाफ़ केवल वज़ीर अली ही नहीं बल्कि दक्षिण में टीपू सुल्तान तथा बंगाल के नवाब का भाई शमसुद्दौला भी है। इन्होंने अफ़गानिस्तान के बादशाह शाहेज़मा को आक्रमण के लिए आमत्रंण दिया है। यह सब सुनकर लेफ़्टीनेंट को आभास हुआ कि कंपनी के खिलाफ़ पूरे हिन्दूस्तान में लहर दौड़ गई है और सभी भारतवासी उन्हें अपने देश के बहार खदेरना चाहते <span id="5_TRN_k">हैं|</span>

</div>
</div>
</div>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>वज़ीर अली ने कंपनी के वकील का कत्ल क्यों किया?</title>
		<link>http://nxtclass.cu.cc/%e0%a4%b5%e0%a4%9c%e0%a4%bc%e0%a5%80%e0%a4%b0-%e0%a4%85%e0%a4%b2%e0%a5%80-%e0%a4%a8%e0%a5%87-%e0%a4%95%e0%a4%82%e0%a4%aa%e0%a4%a8%e0%a5%80-%e0%a4%95%e0%a5%87-%e0%a4%b5%e0%a4%95%e0%a5%80%e0%a4%b2/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 30 Jan 2012 15:45:53 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>arkokoley</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://nxtclass.cu.cc/?p=79</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<div>
<div id="tabs">
<div id="optionContent1">

वज़ीर अली को उसके नवाबी पद से हटा देने पर बनारस भेज दिया गया। फिर कलकत्ता बुलाया गया तो वज़ीर अली ने कंपनी के वकील, जो बनारस में रहता था, उससे शिकायत की, परन्तु उसने शिकायत सुनने की जगह अली को खरीखोटी सुनाई। इस पर वज़ीर अली का जो गुस्सा अंग्रेजो के खिलाफ था और भी ज्यादा बढ गया और उसने इसी गुस्से में वकील का कत्ल कर दिया।

</div>
</div>
</div>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>निम्नलिखित का आशय स्पष्ट कीजिए −  मुट्ठीभर आदमी और इतना दमखम।</title>
		<link>http://nxtclass.cu.cc/%e0%a4%a8%e0%a4%bf%e0%a4%ae%e0%a5%8d%e0%a4%a8%e0%a4%b2%e0%a4%bf%e0%a4%96%e0%a4%bf%e0%a4%a4-%e0%a4%95%e0%a4%be-%e0%a4%86%e0%a4%b6%e0%a4%af-%e0%a4%b8%e0%a5%8d%e0%a4%aa%e0%a4%b7%e0%a5%8d%e0%a4%9f/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 30 Jan 2012 15:55:05 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>arkokoley</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://nxtclass.cu.cc/?p=82</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<div>
<div id="tabs">
<div id="optionContent1">

प्रस्तुत पंक्ति वज़ीर अली के साहस और वीरता का परिचय देती है। वह थोड़े से सैनिकों के साथ जंगल में रह रहा था। अंग्रेज़ों की पूरी फ़ौज उसका पीछा कर रही थी फिर भी उसे पकड़ नहीं पाई।

</div>
</div>
</div>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>The Letter</title>
		<link>http://nxtclass.cu.cc/x/eng/the-letter/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 08 Mar 2012 18:54:57 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>rupesh</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://nxtclass.cu.cc/?page_id=675</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<div id="accordion" class="accordion">
<div class="accordion-group">
<div class="accordion-heading"><a class="accordion-toggle" href="#introduction" data-parent="accordion" data-toggle="collapse">Introduction</a></div>
<div id="introduction" class="accordion-body collapse">

Dhumaketu (1892-1965), the pen name of Gaurishankar Govardhandas Josh, was prolific writer. He is considered to be a pioneer of the Gujarati short story. In this story the postmaster comes to realize the agony of the coachman Ali, separated from his daughter, when he finds himself in his state. The anxiety to receive some news about his ailing daughter makes him understand the anxiety of the coachman to receive a letter from his long separated daughter. He realizes how much painful the separation in love is!

</div>
</div>
<div id="accordion" class="accordion">
<div class="accordion-group">
<div class="accordion-heading"><a class="accordion-toggle" href="#story" data-parent="accordion" data-toggle="collapse">Story</a></div>
<div id="story" class="accordion-body collapse">

Dhumaketu can be glorified as a prolific writer who has given a very vivid and wonderful description of the village and its people, along with the nature and loneliness of human beings. The story talks about coachman Ali who could not bear the pain of separation when his daughter left after her marriage. His loneliness gained momentum with passage of time in which he desperately waited for a letter from his daughter Miriam.

The story begins with a very vivid description of how silent the village was “wrapped in deathly silence.” The description of it being early dawn and people fast asleep in a winter morning is very well portrayed through various phrases such as “early dawn stars”, “distant steps”, “occasional bark of dogs”, etc. The old man goes to the post-office everyday occupying a particular seat with a fixed purpose - awaiting a letter from his daughter. People found him to be a lunatic and laughed at him.

In the following lines of the story we find Ali missing from the post-office for several days as he falls sick terribly. At last, he reaches the place one day and asks for the much awaited letter. The postmaster gets infuriated and chases him away. Although this angers Ali, he doesn't lose his temper. He gives five golden guineas to the postmaster to forward his letter to his grave as he considers that very day to be his last day of survival. He was never seen again.

The turning point in the story comes when trouble knocks on the postmaster's door in the form of a news about his own daughter who lay sick in another town. He was anxious about receiving a letter from her, discussing her health. He searched in the pile of letters and to his shock, found Ali's much awaited letter from his daughter. His anger disappeared in a whiff and he sent for the postman to send it to Ali right away.

The story hear turns quite heart-rendering when the postmaster feels empathy towards Ali. He is grieved because of his condition and is filled with sympathy for the old man. He then personally went to the post office to give Ali the letter. To his amazement, Ali received the letter with gratefulness and tears in his eyes. The postmaster shrunk back when he noticed a light of kindness when Ali received the letter.

The postmaster narrated this entire story to the postman. When asked on whom he saw the postmaster said he saw Ali. This is when he came to know that Ali had died three months before. Here, the bewildered postmaster found at the doorway that Ali had disappeared. Imagination had deceived him. That evening he went to Ali's grave and laid the letter there.

Empathy makes us understand each other and build strong relationships. One can feel the anxiety of other when one finds himself in that particular situation. In the end of the story, tortured with remorse and grief, the postmaster waits for news from her ill daughter, passing a restless night beside the charcoal sigri.

</div>
</div>
<div id="accordion" class="accordion">
<div class="accordion-group">
<div class="accordion-heading"><a class="accordion-toggle" href="#characters" data-parent="accordion" data-toggle="collapse">Characters</a></div>
<div id="characters" class="accordion-body collapse">

<strong>Ali:</strong>
Ali is the central character. He has deep love for his daughter who was married to a soldier. Separation from her makes him compassionate. He gives up hunting innocent animals. He becomes worried and anxious when he receives no letter from his daughter. He begins to visit the post office daily. Years passes but he receives no letter. His condition becomes pathetic. But such is the power of love that he becomes strong enough to withstand all words of ridicule hurled at him daily by the heartless employees of the post office. His health deteriorates and he dies one day.

<strong>Postmaster:</strong>
In the beginning, the postmaster is a heartless, callous person. He is an ill-tempered person. He loses his patience with Ali who comes to disturb them everyday in the post office. He calls him a pest. but one day he finds himself in the condition of Ali. He becomes anxious to receive the letter from his daughter who has fallen ill in the distance town. Now he realizes Ali's suffering and the value of the letter. He becomes compassionate. When he finds a letter from Ali's daughter, he puts it in reverently on Ali's grave. He is now a changed person.

</div>
</div>
<div id="accordion" class="accordion">
<div class="accordion-group">
<div class="accordion-heading"><a class="accordion-toggle" href="#title" data-parent="accordion" data-toggle="collapse">Title</a></div>
<div id="title" class="accordion-body collapse">

The title of the story 'The Letter' is quite appropriate.I t brings home the value of the letter, symbol of ones love and concern. It begins with the coachman Ali's long anxious wait for a letter from his married daughter. Five years have passed and there is no letter. Post office employees make fun of him. But love of his daughter make him mentally strong and patient enough to withstand all their ridicules. One day he dies. The callous postmaster suddenly fonds him in Al's condition he is anxious to receive a letter from his ailing daughter. When he finds a letter from a Ali's daughter he realizes the value of a letter. A letter, he comes to understand, is not mere piece of paper. He visits Ali's grave and places the letter on it in reverence.

</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>]]></content:encoded>

	</item>
	<item>
		<title>The Frog and the Nightingle</title>
		<link>http://nxtclass.cu.cc/x/eng/the-frog-and-the-nightingale/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 08 Mar 2012 19:00:36 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>rupesh</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://nxtclass.cu.cc/?page_id=679</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[[abpoet text='Vikram Seth is a product of the Doon school. Later he went abroad for the further studies in England and America. The subjects of his study were philosophy, politics and economics. During his stay in china, he also studied poetry and languages at Nanjing university. In the 'Frog and the Nightingale', he brings about the foolishness of following anybody blind.
']

[abpoem text='The poem "The Frog and The Nightingale" is about the contest between the frog and the nightingale. The nightingale is credulous and simple minded, whereas the frog is cunning and clever. the frog feels proud of his singing from evening till morning. He claims that he is the best singer. He arranges concerts and charges and admission fee and earns a lot of money.

The frog is surprised to hear the sweet melody of the nightingale. He fears that his position as the only singer of the bob will be threatened by the song of the nightingale. His fear comes true. All the birds listen to the songs of the nightingale and praise her very much. This makes the frog sad.

The frog feels jealous of the popularity of the nightingale. He introduces himself to the nightingale as the owner of the tree. He says that he is a music critic. He takes the nightingale into the confidence and makes an evil plan to get rid of her. He makes her sing excessively for long hours. He starts pointing out her mistakes and drawbacks. The result is that the nightingale has to bear scoldings and exploitation at the hands of the frog. She loses the beauty of her voice. The other creatures stop coming to her at the concerts arranged by the cunning frog. Ultimately, the nightingale dies after she has Brut one of her veins. The frog continues to sing in a loud, unpleasant way, now unchallenged.']
<div class="accordion-group">
<div class="accordion-heading"><a class="accordion-toggle" href="#ldpoem" data-toggle="collapse" data-parent="accordion">Literary Divices in the Poem</a></div>
<div id="ldpoem" class="accordion-body collapse">
<ol>
	<li><strong>Rhyme Scheme:</strong>
The rhyme scheme of the poem is : aa bb cc dd.. ... ..</li>
	<li><strong>Allusion:</strong>
The example of the allusion is : 'And you're Mozart in disguise'.</li>
</ol>
</div>
</div>]]></content:encoded>

	</item>
	<item>
		<title>Mirror</title>
		<link>http://nxtclass.cu.cc/x/eng/mirror/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 08 Mar 2012 19:18:04 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>rupesh</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://nxtclass.cu.cc/?page_id=690</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<div id="accordion" class="accordion">
<div class="accordion-group">
<div class="accordion-heading"><a class="accordion-toggle" href="#introduction" data-toggle="collapse" data-parent="accordion">Introduction</a></div>
<div id="introduction" class="accordion-body collapse">

Sylvia Path (1932-1963) was born in Massachusetts on October 27, 1932. She was a small child when she lost her father. Her life was full of bad experiences. She won the Pulitzer Prize for poetry in 1982. She was bright and intelligent. 'Mirror' reflects her concern with ageing.

</div>
</div>
<div id="accordion" class="accordion">
<div class="accordion-group">
<div class="accordion-heading"><a class="accordion-toggle" href="#abpoem" data-toggle="collapse" data-parent="accordion">About the Poem</a></div>
<div id="abpoem" class="accordion-body collapse">

The mirror is the person (speaker/narrator) of the poem. It is transparent and accurate. It truly reflects what is before it. It is free from prejudices. It is not cruel. It is only truthful. Most of the time it keeps on reflecting the blank wall with some spots opposite it, except when somebody comes before it or when there is darkness.

The mirror is like a lake of water. A woman comes and bends over it as it would bend upon a lake. She looks at her figure. Unable to face the truth, she goes away. She turns to the moon and the candles. In their dim-light she hopes to conceal the ravages of time on her face and figure. When she turns away from it, it reflects her back faithfully. The mirror gets her tears as reward. The mirror knows that the woman has lost her youth. She has been using the mirror ever since she was a young girl. Now when she comes before it, she is horrified to see an old woman rising towards her day after day like a terrible fish.

</div>
</div>
<div id="accordion" class="accordion">
<div class="accordion-group">
<div class="accordion-heading"><a class="accordion-toggle" href="#ldpoem" data-toggle="collapse" data-parent="accordion">Literary Devices In The Poem</a></div>
<div id="ldpoem" class="accordion-body collapse">
<ol>
	<li><strong>Personification:
</strong>(mirror has been imaged as a person)</li>
	<li><strong>Metaphor:
</strong>I m a lake.</li>
</ol>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>]]></content:encoded>

	</item>
	<item>
		<title>Not Marble not the Glided Monuments</title>
		<link>http://nxtclass.cu.cc/x/eng/not-marble-not-the-glided-monuments/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 09 Mar 2012 06:17:08 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>rupesh</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://nxtclass.cu.cc/?page_id=712</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[[abpoet text='

William Shakespeare (1564-1616) was born in Stratford-upon-Avon. He is regarded as the greatest dramatist of all time. He wrote 154 sonnets, too long narrative poems and about three dozen plays. He is known for his profound understanding of human nature in his plays. He has an imaginative and creative mind, but he invents few plots and stories. He simply takes an old play and old poem, and by the sheer force of his imagination, he makes it more wonderful than the old.

But in his sonnets, he expresses his own personal feelings. Most of his sonnets are remarkable for their stubble thought and exquisite expressions. Some critic regard his sonnets as mere literary exercises, but others regard them as the expression of some personal grief. Their are still other who divide his sonnets into two classes, addressed to a man who was his friend and a woman who disclaimed his love.

'] ]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>712</wp:post_id>

		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>

	</item>
	<item>
		<title>कारतूस</title>
		<link>http://nxtclass.cu.cc/x/hindi/%e0%a4%95%e0%a4%be%e0%a4%b0%e0%a4%a4%e0%a5%82%e0%a4%b8/</link>
		<pubDate>Sat, 10 Mar 2012 20:13:20 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>rupesh</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://nxtclass.cu.cc/?page_id=794</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[[summary text="

'कारतूस' कहानी हमें अपने देश के जाबांज और सूरमाओं की याद दिलाती है। इसके लेखक हबीब तनवीर हैं। कहीं-न-कहीं हम इन्हें भूल चूके हैं। हमारे देश की मिट्टी से जन्मे हज़ारों सूरमाओं ने अपने पराक्रम से अंग्रेज़ों को कहने पर विवश कर दिया था कि यह देश वीरों का देश है। अंग्रेज़ों ने भारत में प्रवेश किया था, तब वे एक व्यापारी थे। इन्होंने धोखे से हमारे देश पर कब्जा कर लिया। लोगों को जब तक होश आया, तब तक बहुत देर हो चुकी थी। अनेकों वीरों ने देश को स्वतंत्रता दिलाने के लिए प्रयास आरंभ किए। उन्होंने अपने साहस और पराक्रम से अंग्रेज़ों की गहरी हो चुकी नींव को हिलाकर रख दिया था। इन्हीं वीरों में से एक वीर था, लखनऊ का नवाब वज़ीर अली। उसने अग्रेज़ों के आगे घुटने टेकने से अच्छा, उनके साथ लड़ना ज्यादा बेहतर समझा। उसे गुलामी की सोने से बनी बेड़ियों से अधिक जंगलों में आज़ादी की खुली हवा अधिक प्यारी लगी। उसे पकड़ने के लिए अंग्रेज़ी सरकार जाल बुन रही थी। वे जंगलों में उसे पकड़ने के उद्देश्य से खेमा गाड़े खड़ी थी। वज़ीर अली एक निडर व्यक्ति था। वह बिना डरे कर्नल के खेमे में जा पहुँचा और उसकी नाक के नीचे से कारतूस लेकर चला गया। उसके साहस से हैरान कर्नल को भी उसके साहस की प्रशंसा करने पर विवश होना पड़ा था।

"]

[ncert text="

aaa

"] ]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>%e0%a4%95%e0%a4%be%e0%a4%b0%e0%a4%a4%e0%a5%82%e0%a4%b8</wp:post_name>
		<wp:status>publish</wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>242</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>
		<wp:post_type>page</wp:post_type>
		<wp:post_password></wp:post_password>
		<wp:is_sticky>0</wp:is_sticky>

			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[4]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_flattr_post_language</wp:meta_key>

		<title>Home</title>

		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>813</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2012-03-11 15:07:29</wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt>2012-03-11 09:37:29</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>home</wp:post_name>

	<item>
		<title>How do Organisms Reproduce?</title>
		<link>http://nxtclass.cu.cc/x/bio/how-do-organisms-reproduce/</link>
		<pubDate>Sun, 11 Mar 2012 17:40:52 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>admin</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://nxtclass.cu.cc/?page_id=826</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[[summary text='
1. In asexual reproduction, certain body cells undergo repeated mitotic divisions and give rise to two or more new organisms of the same kind.

2. Different methods of asexual reproduction are — fission, budding, fragmentation, spore formation, regeneration, vegetative propagation, parthenogenesis and tissue culture.

3. Fission is a process of division of a single celled organism into two or many cells (called binary and multiple fission respectively), e.g., Amoeba.

4. Budding is a method of reproduction in which a protuberance develops on the mature organism’s body, attains full maturity and then detaches, e.g., Yeast and Hydra.

5. Spore formation : Spores are special cells formed within special structures called ‘sporangia’ that disseminate and can form the entire plant. This is exclusive to the plant kingdom, e.g., mushroom, ferns and mosses.

6. Vegetative propagation is a method of reproduction in which a vegetative plant part (i.e., a nonreproductive part or a non-flowering part) produces a new plant.

7. For artificial propagation by man, the commonly used methods are:
<ul>
	<li>Cutting in which a stem is given an oblique cut and the cut stem is kept under appropriate conditions to give rise to an entirely new plant, e.g., Rose and China rose.</li>
	<li>Layering is a process in which the stem, while still attached to the mother plant is burried under the soil for a while, till it strikes new roots. It is then detached from the mother plant, e.g., Jasmine. This is called ‘soil layering’. The other form of layering is ‘air layering’ in which incision is made on the bark of a tree and covered with moist soil. When rooting takes place in the cut portion, the entire portion is cut and used for propagation.</li>
	<li>Grafting is a process in which two parts of different plants are joined by bandaging them tightly. This allows cambial activity to unite the two portions. The one that contributes the root is called ‘stock’ and the one that contributes the shoot is known as ‘scion’. Bicoloured roses and different varieties of mangoes are made by this method.</li>
</ul>
8. Advantages of Vegetative Propagation
<ul>
	<li>It allows quicker and easy propagation.</li>
	<li>Better qualities of the plants can be maintained and the quality can even be enhanced as in seedless oranges.</li>
	<li>It results in propagation of those plants which do not produce viable seeds or produce seeds with prolonged period of dormancy.</li>
</ul>
9. Disadvantages of Vegetative Propagation

Most of these propagated plants do not produce viable seeds and hence curtail natural reproduction.

10. Regeneration is the ability of an organism to replace or repair any lost part. Sometimes, an entire organism can be made from its fragmented body, e.g., Planaria. When an unfertilised egg can be made to develop into an entire organism, it is known as ‘Parthenogenesis’ in animals and ‘Parthenocarpy’ in plants.

11. The reproductive part of a plant is its flower. A complete flower has four whorls —sepals, petals, androecium and gynoecium.

12. Male gametes are the pollen grains produced by the anther lobes and the female gametes are the ova within ovules present inside ovaries.

13. The transfer of pollen grains from the anther to the stigma is known as pollination.

14. Pollination &gt;&gt; Self     - In same flower, In two flowers of same plant
&gt;&gt; Cross  - Transfer of pollen from anther to the stigma of different flower of different plants but of same species.

15. Upon pollination, pollen gets deposited on the stigma. The pollen germinates by forming pollen tubes. Each tube carries two male nuclei at its tip.

16. The ovary bears ovules. The number of ovules vary from one (as in mango) to many (as in orchid).

17. During syngamy, the first male nucleus fuses with the ovum to form the zygote. The second male nucleus fuses with the polar nucleus to form the endosperm.

18. The entire process is summarised as “double fertilisation” and triple fusion.

19. The fertilised ovule develops into a seed and the fertilised ovary into the fruit.

20. Sexual reproduction necessarily requires two gametes usually different from one another. Male gamete is the spermatozoa and female gamete is the ovum.

21. In most animals single individual produces only one type of gamete and hence is unisexual. However, there are organisms that possess both testicles and ovaries and are called bisexuals or hermaphrodites, e.g., earthworm and leech.

22. The fusion of the two gametes is known as ‘fertilisation’.

23. Sexual reproduction provides wider scope for variation between the parents and the offsprings.

24. Male reproductive system in human consists of the following organs —
<ul>
	<li>Testes in the scrotum</li>
	<li>Epididymis</li>
	<li>Vas deferens</li>
	<li>Urethra</li>
	<li>Penis</li>
	<li>Accessory glands (seminal vesicle and prostrate gland)</li>
</ul>
25. Female reproductive system in humans consists of the following organs —
<ul>
	<li>Ovaries</li>
	<li>Fallopian tubes or oviducts</li>
	<li>Uterus or womb</li>
	<li>Vagina</li>
</ul>
26. The attainment of sexual maturity is known as puberty.

27. The gonads control and regulate three major functions :
<ul>
	<li>Produce the gametes as well as the sex hormones (testosterone is produced by the testicles and estrogen and progesterone by the ovaries).</li>
	<li>They help in the functioning of the accessory sex organs (i.e., organs which are part of the reproductive system but do not directly produce gametes).</li>
	<li>They help in the development of secondary sex characters like breast development in girls and growth of facial hair in boys.</li>
</ul>
28. In male the testicles are lodged in the scrotum outside the body as the process of sperm formation requires a temperature lower than the normal body temperature. The other parts of this system are :
<ul>
	<li>Vas deferens</li>
	<li>Urethra, a common passage for the release of urine as well as sperms. Testicles function throughout the life of a man, from puberty onwards, though the quality of the sperms declines with age.</li>
</ul>
29. The female puberty is considered to be attained with the first menstrual discharge and this is called ‘Menarche’. The stoppage of menstruation marks the end of the reproductive life in females and is known as ‘Menopause’.

30. The ovaries at birth contain groups of cells called follicles, which mature one at a time throughout the reproductive life of a female in a cyclical manner. Out of a group of follicles only one matures as an ovum or egg. The other cells in the group serve as nourishers. Upon attaining maturity the egg is expelled into the oviduct also known as the fallopian tube.

31. Population control involves measures by which fertilisation is prevented. The three common methods are :
<ul>
	<li>Physical barrier methods like condoms or placing of IUCDs (Intra Uterine Contraceptive Devices) in the uterus of the female.</li>
	<li>Chemical methods like use of oral or vaginal pills.</li>
	<li>Surgical methods which involves a reversible surgery in which the tubes conducting the gametes are cut and tied. It is known as vasectomy in males and tubectomy in females.</li>
</ul>
32. STDs are sexually transmitted diseases, also called Veneral Diseases (VDs). They are transmitted from the infected individuals to healthy ones during sexual contacts. Gonorrhoea and syphilis are common STDs. AIDS (Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome) is also transmitted by sexual contact. Responsible sexual behaviour and prudence can help to prevent the spread of STDs. Both government (National Population Policy and National Health Policy) and non-government organisations are endeavouring to control the fertility rate.
']

[ncert text="

<strong>1. What is the importance of DNA coping in reproduction?</strong>

Ans. Importance of DNA coping in reproduction is that the characteristics, of the parent organisms are transmitted to its offspring and at the sometime some occasional variations are also produced in the offspring.

<strong>2. Why is variation beneficial to the species but not necessarily for the individual?</strong>

Ans. Variation is beneficial to the species as it helps in the survival of a few individual under extreme conditions when the rest of the population is wiped out. Hod this variation not been there, the population in a niche would be wiped out, if the niche were drastically altered. Thus, this variation ensures the survival of the species.

<strong>3. How does binary fission differ from multiple fission?</strong>

Ans. When two new daughter cells are formed as a result of fission, it Is called binary fission, e.g. Amoeba. When multiple daughter cells are formed as a result of fission, it is called multiple fission, e.g. malarial parasite.

<strong>4. How will an organism be benefited if it reproduces through spores?</strong>

Ans. An organism is benefited if it reproduces through spores as spores formation is an asexual form of reproduction and the organism does not need a partner to reproduce. Also, the offspring’s produced are multiple that can spread out far.

<strong>5. Can you think of reasons why more complex organisms cannot give rise to new individuals through regeneration?</strong>

Ans. Complex organisms have specialized cells, tissues and organs that have to be placed at definite positions in the body. In such complexly organisms, it is not easy to develop new organisms through regenerations. Hence, complex organisms through regeneration.

<strong>6. Why is vegetation propagation practiced for growing some types of plants?</strong>

Ans. Vegetation propagation through methods like layering, grafting, etc. allows the plants raised to bear flowers and fruits earlier than those produced from seeds. This is why vegetative propagation is practised for growing some types of plants.

<strong>7. Why is DNA copying an essential part of the process of reproduction?</strong>

Ans. DNA contains information for making some specialize protein that lead to the body design and structure. Thus DNA coping ensures that the offspring has a body design similar to that of the parent. Thus, in turn fulfills one of the aims of reproduction, i.e., to produce similar organisms.

<strong>8. How is the process of pollination different from fertilization?</strong>

Ans. Pollination refers to the transfer of pollen grains from the anther the stigma by agents like air and water. On the other hand, fertilization refers to the fusion of male and female germ cell into zygote that later develops into a seed in plants.

<strong>9. What is the role of the seminal vesicle’s and prostate gland?</strong>

Ans. The seminal vesicle’s and the prostate gland secrete fluids into the vas defers that help in easy movement of the sperms and provides them nourishment.

<strong>10. What are the changes seen in girls at the time of puberty?</strong>

Ans. Various changes take place in girls at the time of puberty. Thick hair grows in the armpits and the genital area between the thighs, which ca also become darker in colour. The breast size begins to increase, with the darkening of skin of the nipples at the tip of the breasts. Girls also begin to menstruate at around this time.

<strong>11. How does the embryo get nourishment inside the mother’s body?</strong>

Ans. The embryo gets nutrition from the mother’s body through the placenta. It is dose embedded in the uterine wall with villi on the embryos’ side which absorb glucose and oxygen from the blood spaces that surround them on the mother’s side.

<strong>12. If a woman is using copper-T, will it help in protecting her from sexually transmitted diseases?</strong>

Ans:- No using copper-T will not provide protection from sexually transmitted diseases, as it does not prevent the entry of semen, It only prevents the implantation of the embryo in the uterus

<strong>13. What are the advantages of sexual reproduction over asexually reproduction?</strong>

Ans:- The advantages of sexual reproduction over asexual reproduction are

(1). as the DNA is inherited from two different parents, more variations are produced, ensuring the species survival

(2). Variations are more available in sexual mode them in asexual

(3). the organism formed has the, characteristics of both the parents

<strong>14. What are the functions performed by the testis in human being?</strong>

Ans. In human being, the testis produces sperms or the male germs cells. It is main male reproductive organ.it also secretes the hormone, testosterone that brings about secondary sexual characteristics in human males.

<strong>15. Why does menstruation occur?</strong>

Ans.  When the ovary release an egg, the uterus prepares itself to receive the egg. The living become thick and spongy to nourish the embryo if fertilization takes place .however if the egg is not fertilized, the lining berks and come out of the vagina as blood and mucous known as menstruation. This why menstruation takes place.

<strong>16. What are the different methods of contraception?</strong>

Ans. The different methods of contraception are:

1)   Physical: condoms on penis or similar devices worn in the vagina create a physical or mechanical barrier so that the sperm does not reach the egg other devices like the loop and copper-T placed in the uterus prevent the implantation of the embryo in the uterus.

2)    Chemical: use of contraception pills change the hormonal balance of the body so that the eggs are not released.

3)   Surgical: Surgical methods like male vasectomy and female tubectomy create blocks in the vas defer the fallopian tubes and prevent the release of sperms or eggs from the testes or the ovary.

<strong>17. What could the reason for adopting contraceptive methods?</strong>

Ans. There could be various reasons for adopting contra captive methods:
<ol>
	<li>To prevent unwanted pregnancies</li>
	<li> To protect oneself from sexually transmitted diseases like syphilis, HIV-AIDS etc.</li>
</ol>
"] ]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>The Rise of Nationalism in Europe</title>
		<link>http://nxtclass.cu.cc/x/his/the-rise-of-nationalism-in-europe/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 23 Mar 2012 10:46:20 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>rupesh</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://nxtclass.cu.cc/?page_id=896</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<strong>How did Frederic Sorrieu depicted the utopian vision in his paintings ?
OR
How did the French artist Frederic Sorrieu visualized in his first print of series of four prints visualizing his dream of a world made up of 'Democratic and Social Republics'.</strong>

Ans:
<ul>
	<li>The first print of the series, shows the peoples of Europe and America – men and women of all ages and social classes – marching in a long train, and offering homage to the statue of Liberty as they pass by it.</li>
	<li>A female figure was shown with the torch of Enlightenment in one hand and Charter of Rights of Man in another hand.</li>
	<li>On the earth in the foreground of the image lie the shattered remains of the symbols of absolutist institutions.</li>
	<li>In Sorrieu’s utopian vision, the peoples of the world are grouped as distinct nations, identified through their flags and national costume.</li>
</ul>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>896</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2012-03-23 16:16:20</wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt>2012-03-23 10:46:20</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>the-rise-of-nationalism-in-europe</wp:post_name>
		<wp:status>publish</wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>205</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>
		<wp:post_type>page</wp:post_type>

	<item>
		<title>टोपी शुक्ला</title>
		<link>http://nxtclass.cu.cc/%e0%a4%9f%e0%a5%8b%e0%a4%aa%e0%a5%80-%e0%a4%b6%e0%a5%81%e0%a4%95%e0%a5%8d%e0%a4%b2%e0%a4%be/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 30 Jan 2012 18:45:53 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>arkokoley</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://nxtclass.cu.cc/?p=87</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<div><span style="font-size: small;"><span style="line-height: normal;">'टोपी शुक्ला' कहानी प्रेम के महत्व का वर्णन करती है। इस कहानी में लेखक राही मासूम रज़ा ने बताने का प्रयास किया है कि प्रेम जाति, धर्म, और उम्र के बधनों से परे है। प्रेम एक सुंदर भावना है। उसके सामने हर दुर्भावना और दुख निष्फल हो जाता है। </span></span></div>
<div></div>
<div><span style="font-size: small;"><span style="line-height: normal;">टोपी, इफ़्फ़न का मित्र है। इफ़्फ़न शहर के कलेक्टर का पुत्र है और मुस्लिम परिवार से है। टोपी ब्राह्मण है परंतु दोनों के लिए पद और धर्म का कोई महत्व नहीं है। वे दोनों पक्के मित्र हैं। यही उनकी पहचान है। </span></span></div>
<div></div>
<div><span style="font-size: small;"><span style="line-height: normal;">वहीं इफ़्फ़न की दादी उम्र दराज़ महिला हैं। टोपी और उनके बीच घनिष्ट संबंध है। टोपी, इफ़्फ़न के घर सिर्फ उसकी दादी से मिलने जाता है। टोपी की अपनी दादी भी है। परंतु उनसे उन्हें कभी प्रेम और स्नेह की कोमल छाया नहीं मिली। मिला है तो डाँट, अविश्वास और अपमान। इफ़्फ़न की दादी उसे अपनी दादी से ज्यादा प्यारी लगती है। उसे इस बात से कोई सरोकार नहीं है कि वह मुस्लिम है। उसके लिए तो वह संसार की सबसे प्यारी दादी है।</span></span></div>
<div></div>
<div><span style="font-size: small;"><span style="line-height: normal;">लेखक इस कहानी में टोपी शुक्ला के माध्यम से यह प्रश्न उठाते हैं कि समाज में क्या ज्यादा महत्वपूर्ण है, प्रेम, धर्म, जाति या कुछ और। इस कहानी ने अपनी बात को बहुत सुंदर ढ़ग से व्यक्त किया है।</span></span></div>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>87</wp:post_id>

		<wp:status>publish</wp:status>

	<item>
		<title>इफ़्फ़न की दादी अपने पीहर क्यों जाना चाहती थीं?</title>
		<link>http://nxtclass.cu.cc/%e0%a4%87%e0%a4%ab%e0%a4%bc%e0%a5%8d%e0%a4%ab%e0%a4%bc%e0%a4%a8-%e0%a4%95%e0%a5%80-%e0%a4%a6%e0%a4%be%e0%a4%a6%e0%a5%80-%e0%a4%85%e0%a4%aa%e0%a4%a8%e0%a5%87-%e0%a4%aa%e0%a5%80%e0%a4%b9%e0%a4%b0/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 30 Jan 2012 19:11:23 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>arkokoley</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://nxtclass.cu.cc/?p=90</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<div>
<div id="tabs">
<div id="optionContent1">

इफ़्फ़न की दादी मौलवी की बेटी न होकर ज़मीदार की बेटी थीं। अपने पीहर में वह दूध, घी, दही खाती थीं। लखनऊ आकर वह इसके लिए तरस जाती क्योंकि यहाँ उन्हें मौलविन बन कर रहना पड़ता था। इसलिए उन्हें पीहर जाना अच्छा लगता था।

</div>
</div>
</div>]]></content:encoded>
