	<item>
		<title>Two tangents are drawn to a circle from an external point A, touching the circle at B and C. From Another point K a third tangent is drawn to the circle intersecting AB in P and AC in R and touching the circle at Q. If AB = 20 cm, then what is the perimeter of triangle ABC?</title>
		<link>http://nxtclass.cu.cc/two-tangents-are-drawn-to-a-circle-from-an-external-point-a-touching-the-circle-at-b-and-c-from-another-point-k-a-third-tangent-is-drawn-to-the-circle-intersecting-ab-in-p-and-ac-in-r-and-touching-t/</link>
		<pubDate>Sat, 04 Feb 2012 06:58:32 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>admin</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://nxtclass.cu.cc/?p=110</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<span style="font-size: x-small"><span style="line-height: normal">Since tangents from an external point to a circle are equal in length
<img src="http://203.196.176.41/VLEBT_RootRepository/Resources/3c0a76ab-d178-42c8-9de2-53bf89d1f51e.jpg" alt="" width="204" height="168" />
PQ = PB (tangents from P)
QR = RC (tangents from R)
AB = AC (tangents from A)
Now perimeter of</span></span>

<span style="font-size: x-small"><span style="line-height: normal"> <img src="http://203.196.176.41/VLEBT_RootRepository/Resources/b04991ab-2681-4fdb-9228-405a3ae8b2f3.gif" alt="" width="177" height="21" />

	<item>
		<title>In a right triangle ABC, right angled at B BC = 15 cm and AB = 8 cm. A circle is inscribed in triangle ABC. What is radius of the circle?</title>
		<link>http://nxtclass.cu.cc/in-a-right-triangle-abc-right-angled-at-b-bc-15-cm-and-ab-8-cm-a-circle-is-inscribed-in-triangle-abc-what-is-radius-of-the-circle/</link>
		<pubDate>Sat, 04 Feb 2012 07:00:03 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>arkokoley</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://nxtclass.cu.cc/?p=118</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[3 cm
<img src="http://203.196.176.41/VLEBT_RootRepository/Resources/b4bf985c-a3fb-4eb7-9907-1050d688ffef.gif" alt="" width="249" height="32" />
<img src="http://203.196.176.41/VLEBT_RootRepository/Resources/8cdb72c5-1c90-4742-83c2-a27aef8d2b67.gif" alt="" width="213" height="27" />
<img src="http://203.196.176.41/VLEBT_RootRepository/Resources/4c2d1074-24b7-4175-947b-2d729ecaca48.jpg" alt="" width="204" height="184" />
Clearly OPBQ is a square.
<img src="http://203.196.176.41/VLEBT_RootRepository/Resources/2bee99c9-2abb-47e4-a7bd-e644999f272e.gif" alt="" width="220" height="21" />
<img src="http://203.196.176.41/VLEBT_RootRepository/Resources/1f3c1a63-71d9-4d92-a13f-61b1d196c690.gif" alt="" width="245" height="27" />
<img src="http://203.196.176.41/VLEBT_RootRepository/Resources/fb7821db-123d-4a16-acba-f641619c0a5b.gif" alt="" width="255" height="27" />
<img src="http://203.196.176.41/VLEBT_RootRepository/Resources/3ed63447-d839-493d-b9a3-7cd3c5ed7765.gif" alt="" width="284" height="21" />
<img src="http://203.196.176.41/VLEBT_RootRepository/Resources/c7b76b35-d352-4d3c-832b-e96b0832286a.gif" alt="" width="91" height="21" />
<img src="http://203.196.176.41/VLEBT_RootRepository/Resources/b0283d0e-f1f7-4945-aff1-ea689437089b.gif" alt="" width="177" height="21" />]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>118</wp:post_id>

	<item>
		<title>PQ and PT are tangents to a circle with centre O and radius 5 cm. If PQ = 12, then what is the perimeter of quadrilateral PQOT?</title>
		<link>http://nxtclass.cu.cc/pq-and-pt-are-tangents-to-a-circle-with-centre-o-and-radius-5-cm-if-pq-12-then-what-is-the-perimeter-of-quadrilateral-pqot/</link>
		<pubDate>Sat, 04 Feb 2012 07:08:46 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>arkokoley</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://nxtclass.cu.cc/?p=120</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[34 cm

<img src="http://203.196.176.41/VLEBT_RootRepository/Resources/f3bc3ece-1fb0-4e25-b4a5-c9aa71df5811.gif" alt="" width="147" height="21" />
and PQ = PT = 12 cm
<img src="http://203.196.176.41/VLEBT_RootRepository/Resources/175cb6c6-c8d9-4249-a01e-5526fe117255.jpg" alt="" width="264" height="127" />
Perimeter (equal PQOT) = PQ + QO + OT + PT
<img src="http://203.196.176.41/VLEBT_RootRepository/Resources/1d7bb313-2b35-41e5-b992-8e8c50dfc394.gif" alt="" width="196" height="27" />]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>120</wp:post_id>

	<item>
		<title>A tangent PQ at a point P of a circle of radius 5 cm meets a line through the centre O at a point Q such that OQ = 12 cm. Length of PQ is:</title>
		<link>http://nxtclass.cu.cc/a-tangent-pq-at-a-point-p-of-a-circle-of-radius-5-cm-meets-a-line-through-the-centre-o-at-a-point-q-such-that-oq-12-cm-length-of-pq-is/</link>

	<item>
		<title>From a point P which is at a distance of 13 cm from the centre O of a circle of radius 5 cm the pair of tangent PQ and QR to the circle are drawn.  What are the lengths in cm of tangents PQ and PR? </title>
		<link>http://nxtclass.cu.cc/from-a-point-p-which-is-at-a-distance-of-13-cm-from-the-centre-o-of-a-circle-of-radius-5-cm-the-pair-of-tangent-pq-and-qr-to-the-circle-are-drawn-what-are-the-lengths-in-cm-of-tangents-pq-and-pr/</link>
		<pubDate>Sat, 04 Feb 2012 07:12:47 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>arkokoley</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://nxtclass.cu.cc/?p=124</guid>

		<content:encoded><![CDATA[12, 12

	</item>
	<item>
		<title>Human Eye And The Colourful World</title>
		<link>http://nxtclass.cu.cc/human-eye-and-the-colourful-world/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 06 Feb 2012 09:46:30 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>arkokoley</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://nxtclass.cu.cc/?p=130</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<div><dl><dt><strong>Human Eye</strong><a href="http://nxtclass.cu.cc/wp-content/uploads/2012/02/Capture1.png"><img class="aligncenter" src="http://nxtclass.cu.cc/wp-content/uploads/2012/02/Capture1.png" alt="" width="464" height="508" /></a></dt></dl></div>
<ol>
	<li>Cornea is a transparent protective membrane such that it covers the front portion of an eye. It is that portion of an eye which is visible from outside.</li>
	<li>Aqueous humour is the viscous liquid inside eye which lies between cornea and eye lens. It converges most of the light ray entering the eye.</li>
	<li>Iris is the coloured part in our eye. It is a muscular diaphragm that controls the size of pupil. In low light condition, it expands the size of pupil so that more light enters the eye through pupil while in good light condition, it contracts the size of pupil so that less light enters the eye through pupil.</li>
	<li>Pupil is a small hole in iris. It appears black because any light falling on it goes into the eye and the amount of light entering the eye is controlled by changing the size of pupil with the help of iris.</li>
	<li>Crystalline Lens is a lens of adjustable focal length inside eye, so as to focus objects placed at different distances.</li>
	<li>Ciliary Muscles alter the curvature of lens.</li>
	<li>Retina is the place where light entering the eye forms the real and inverted image of an object. It consists of about 125 million cells, called rods and cones which receive the light and about one million opticnerve fibres through which the information is transmitted to the brain. The function of rod cells is to respond to the brightness of light while function of cone cells is to respond to the colours and also to distinguish between various colours.</li>
	<li>Vitreous Humour is the fluid in between the lens and the retina.</li>
	<li>The cornea-lens-fluid system is known as eye-lens or single converging lens whose focal length is adjusted with the help of ciliary muscles.</li>
	<li>Yellow Spot is at about centre of the retina and is most sensitive to the light.</li>
	<li>Blind Spot is the point at which the optic nerve enters the eye. It is insensitive to the light. In other words blind spot is the area of zero vision.</li>
	<li>The size of object as sensed by human eye depends on its visual angle. Visual angle is the angle (8) subtended by object on eye as shown in the given figure. As object is brought nearer to eye, visual angle increases and hence size of image will increase.<img class="aligncenter  wp-image-134" style="border-style: initial;border-color: initial" src="http://nxtclass.cu.cc/wp-content/uploads/2012/02/Untitled1.png" alt="" width="402" height="187" /></li>
	<li>The ability of eye to see objects from infinity ( far point) to 25 cm (near point) is called "power of accommodation." or the ability of the eye lens to adjust its focal length is called power of accommodation.</li>
	<li>If object is at infinity, parallel beam of light enters the eye and in this condition eye is least strained and said to be 'relaxed' or 'unstrained'.If object is at least distance of distinct vision (near paint), eye is under maximum strain and visual angle is maximum.</li>
</ol>
<p style="text-align: left"><strong>Working of The Eye</strong></p>
<p style="text-align: left">When ray of light coming from the object enter the pupil of the eye and falls on the eye lens as shown in figure, it converges the light rays and produces a real and inverted image of the object on the retina. The image formed on the retina is conveyed to the brain by the optic nerve and gives rise to the sensation of vision.</p>
Image formation of an object on retina

<strong>Terms regarding Human Eye</strong>
<ol>
	<li><strong>Fovea </strong>central is : The centre of the retina. The region of the highest visual activity and cone cells density.</li>
	<li><strong>Vitreous gel (body) </strong>: A clear jelly like substance which fills the posterior chamber of the eye ball.</li>
	<li><strong>Macula lutea </strong>: The area in and around the fovea made up mostly of cone cells. It is responsible for central vision and contains the fovea.</li>
	<li><strong>Sclera: </strong>The white dense, fibrous outer coating of the eye ball.</li>
	<li><strong>Iris: </strong>The coloured diaphragm in the anterior chamber of the eye ball which contracts and expands to adjust for light intensity.</li>
	<li><strong>Occulomot</strong><strong>or </strong><strong>mus</strong><strong>cles: </strong>Muscles that move the eyes in all directions.</li>
	<li><strong>Pink eye </strong>: Conjuctivitis.</li>
	<li><strong>Macular degeneration </strong>: A condition when rods and cones degenerate with age.</li>
	<li><strong>Constriction: </strong>When the pupil is very narrow to allow minimum light in.</li>
	<li><strong>Glaucoma: </strong>A condition where internal pressure damages the optic nerve.</li>
	<li><strong>Stye:</strong> An infection of the sebaceous glands of the eyelid.</li>
	<li><strong>Dilation:</strong> When the pupil is wide open to allow maximum light in.</li>
	<li><strong>Opthamologist:</strong> A doctor to consult for an eye condition.</li>
	<li><strong>Optometrist:</strong> A specialist who prescribes eye glasses.</li>
	<li><strong>Blind spot:</strong> If an image is formed on this region of retina, it is not sensed and hence, the object is not seen. There are no rods or cones at this spot where optic nerve leaves the eye ball.</li>
</ol>
<strong>Defects of Vision</strong>

<strong></strong>This occurs when a person is not able to see the Objects distinctly and comfortably without strain on eyes.  It is due to the optical defects of the eye.

<strong>Myopia (Short-sightedness or Near-sightedness)</strong>

In this defect, person is not able to see the distant Objects clearly, however he can see nearby objects clearly.
<ol type="i">
	<li>In this defect, far point O is closer than infinity.</li>
	<li>This defect arises due to increase in aperture of eye-ball or decrease in focal length of eye lens.</li>
	<li>In this defect, the image of parallel rays from distant object is formed in front of retina (figure (ii)).</li>
	<li>This defect can be removed by using spectacles having diverging (concave) lens. P-urpose of using the lens is to produce the image at the far point of object at infinity (figure (iii)).</li>
	<li>Power of lens needed to correct defect is <em>P </em>= <span style="text-decoration: underline"> 1  </span> = <span style="text-decoration: underline"> 1  </span> [Here F is far point in metre]                                                                                                                                                                                           .                                                                                            f         -F</li>
</ol>
<strong>Hypermetropia or Hyperopia (Long-sightedness or Far-sightedness)</strong>

<strong></strong>In this defect, person is not able to see the nearby objects clearly, however he can see the distant objects clearly.
<ol type="i">
	<li>In this defect, near point <em>N </em>is greater than 25 cm (tV) (figure (i)).</li>
	<li>This defect arises due to decrease in aperture of eye-ball or increase in focal length of eye-lens.</li>
	<li>In this defect, the image (i) of nearby objects <em>N </em>is formed behind the retina of the eye (figure (ii)).</li>
	<li>This defect can be removed by using spectacles having converging (convex) lens. Purpose of using the lens is to produce the image at the near point <em>N </em>of object at <em>N </em>(figure (iii)).</li>
	<li>Power of lens needed to correct the defect is <em>P </em>=<span style="text-decoration: underline">  1  </span>= [ <span style="text-decoration: underline">_1_</span> - <span style="text-decoration: underline">_1_</span> ] or <em>P </em>= (4 - <span style="text-decoration: underline">   1   </span> ). [Here N.P. (Nearpoint) should be in metre].                                                                                        .                                                                                                    <em>f       </em>0.25   N.P.                        N.P.</li>
</ol>
<strong>Presbyopia </strong>
<ol type="i">
	<li>The power of accommodation of the eye usually decreases with ageing. For most people, the near point gradually recedes away. Presbyopia is a special kind of hypermetropia.</li>
	<li>Presbyopic person finds it difficult to see nearby objects comfortably and distinctly.</li>
	<li>This defect usually occurs in old age because of gradual weakening of the ciliary muscles and diminishing flexibility of eye-lens and thereby ciliary muscles lose their elasticity and so can not change the focal length of eye-lens effectively.</li>
	<li>Sometimes, a person may suffer from both myopia and hypermetropia. This defect can be corrected by using spectacles having bifocal lenses such that the lower portion of the bifocal lens is a convex lens for seeing nearby objects and the upper portion of the bifocal lens is a concave lens for seeing distant objects.</li>
</ol>
<strong>Astigmatism </strong>
<ol type="i">
	<li>In this defect, person is not able to focus on both horizontal as well as vertical lines simultaneously.</li>
	<li>This defect occurs due to imperfect spherical nature of eye-lens and that's why the focal length of eye-lens in two perpendicular directions becomes different.</li>
	<li>This defect can be corrected by using spectacles having cylindrical lens in a particular direction.</li>
</ol>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Periodic Table</title>
		<link>http://nxtclass.cu.cc/periodic-table/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 09 Feb 2012 13:05:56 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>admin</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://nxtclass.cu.cc/?p=148</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<strong>Need and Why?</strong>
<ol type="i">
	<li>Helps study chemistry of elements systematically.</li>
	<li>Need not remember the properties of all elements seperately but only those of groups and periods.</li>
	<li>Helps understand the gradual change of properties.</li>
	<li>Helps understand relationship between different classes of elements.</li>
</ol>
<strong>Early classifications:-</strong>
<ul>
	<li>On basis on Metals or Non Metals:-</li>
</ul>
<ul>
	<li>Shortcomings-</li>
</ul>
<ul>
	<li>too general,</li>
	<li>could not explain the metallic properties of some non metals.</li>
	<li>On Basis of Valency:-</li>
</ul>
<ul>
	<li>Shortcomings:-</li>
</ul>
<ul>
	<li>could not explain the variable valency of single element.</li>
	<li>Elements with same valency have different properties.</li>
	<li>Dobereiner's Triads (By J. Dobereiner):-
<ul>
	<li>Proposed in 1817.</li>
	<li>3 elements were grouped together according to their atomic mass. The atomic mass of the middle element is approximately equal to the average of the masses of the extreme elements of the groups.</li>
	<li>There is gradation in properties of elements of these triads. eg:-</li>
	<li>Li &lt; Na &lt; K : in respect of displacing H from H<sub>2</sub>O.</li>
	<li>Cl &gt; Br &gt; I : in respect of displacing each other from their compounds.</li>
	<li>Ca &lt; Sr &lt; Ba : in respect of displacing H from H<sub>2</sub>O.</li>
	<li>Thus, the middle element of a triad has an intermediate atomic mass and is properties lie between those elements.</li>
	<li>Shortcomings:- All elements cannot be classified.</li>
	<li>Property Explored:- Relation between atomic mass and properties of elements.</li>
</ul>
</li>
	<li>Newland's Law of Octaves (By John Newland):-</li>
</ul>
<ul>
	<li>Proposed in 1866.</li>
	<li>Newland's Law of Octaves:- When elements are arranged in the order of their increasing atomic masses, the properties of every eighth element is a repetition of the first one.</li>
	<li>Shortcomings:-</li>
</ul>
<ul>
	<li>Was applicable only till Calcium as after that every 8th element was not similar to the first one.</li>
	<li>Several elements were discovered that did not fit into the Newland's Law of Octaves.</li>
	<li>To fit elements in the table two elements (Co &amp; Ni)were put in 1 slot in a column of unlike elements(Cl, F, Br and I).</li>
	<li>Iron (Fe) which resembles Co and Ni in properties, was placed far fr0m them.</li>
	<li>Dobereiner's triads also exist in Newland's Classification of elements.</li>
</ul>
<strong>Mendeleev's Periodic Table (The Original Periodic Table):-</strong>
<ul>
	<li>Mendeleev's Periodic Law:- Proposed in 1869, this law states that properties of elements are dependent on their atomic mass and this dependence is periodic.</li>
	<li>Periodic Table:- Devised in 1869, it was arranged in order of increasing atomic mass. Some places were left for unknown elements, eg.- Scandium; Noble gases later added as a separate column at the end of 19th Century.</li>
</ul>
<ul>
	<li>Main Features:-</li>
<ol type="a">
	<li><strong>Groups and Subgroups </strong>are the columns in the periodic table represented by Roman Numeral I-VIII.</li>
	<li>Each group is <strong>divided in two subgroups</strong>, A &amp; B which are single columned.</li>
	<li><strong>Group VIII B contains 3 sets</strong> of elements each: Fe, Co, Ni.</li>
	<li><strong>Group VIII A has Noble gases</strong>.</li>
	<li>Elements in any subgroup resemble each other.</li>
	<li>Elements of <strong>Subgroup A don't resemble those in Subgroup B</strong>.</li>
	<li><strong>Periods</strong> are the rows which comprise of the entire range of elements after which properties repeat. Represented by Arabic numerals 1-7.</li>
</ol>
	<li>Usefulness:-</li>
</ul>
<ol>
	<li><strong>Valency</strong>:- Elements in a group have the same valency, that changes gradually in a period.</li>
<ul>
	<li>In respect to H -&gt; Rises from 1 to 4 and then falls 4 to 1 gradually moving from left to right.</li>
	<li>In respect to O -&gt; Maximum valency is the same as the group number.</li>
</ul>
	<li>Correction of atomic mass:- Atomic mass of an element is found out by formula: atomic mass = equivalent mass x valency.</li>
</ol>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

		<title>Woo Ad Top Image</title>
		<link>http://nxtclass.cu.cc/?post_type=wooframework&#038;p=434</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>admin</dc:creator>

	<item>
		<title>Woo Logo</title>
		<link>http://nxtclass.cu.cc/?post_type=wooframework&#038;p=435</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>admin</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://nxtclass.cu.cc/?post_type=wooframework&#038;p=435</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>435</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2012-03-05 16:56:35</wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt>0000-00-00 00:00:00</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>closed</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>closed</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>woo-wf-woo_logo</wp:post_name>
